Restlessness points to deficiency of blood and yin; weakness suggests exhaustion leading to weak qi.

To accurately discern the symptoms is to deliberate on methods and remedies. For stabilizing the fetus, Hu Lian is most suitable in pregnancy; a weak fetus may develop, but observe shape and symptoms to avoid errors. Black spirits expel evil blood and can assist with placental expulsion; the Ten Full restores deficiencies and clears yin fire. Unveil the treasures of the spiritual cavity, unlocking the key to the practice of medicine.[102p]
Nurturing the Fetus

After a woman conceives, it is most important to regulate her diet, favoring light and bland flavors, avoiding cold and hot climates, and constantly obtaining pure and peaceful qi to nurture the fetus. This ensures a strong and stable fetal essence, leading to a healthy birth. Nowadays, women tend to indulge in spicy, sour, fried, fatty, sweet, and cold foods, unaware they should restrain their appetites. This harms the spleen and stomach, making it easier for the fetus to miscarry, as the mingling of cold and heat leads to many ailments in the child. Moreover, excessive sourness harms the liver, excess bitterness harms the heart, too much sweetness harms the spleen, and excess spiciness harms the lungs. An overabundance of salt can harm the kidneys, as the foods consumed can injure the vital organs and affect blood, qi, muscles, and bones, leading to the child's diseases. After conception, one must exercise great caution regarding feelings of joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness.[103p]
Excessive joy can harm the heart and disperse energy; anger can injure the liver and raise energy upward; prolonged thinking can damage the spleen and cause energy stagnation; worry can hurt the lungs and lead to energy blockage; fear can affect the kidneys and lower energy. When maternal energy is harmed, the child’s energy corresponds to it, and there is none without injury. If the mother is harmed, miscarriage may easily occur; if the child is harmed, the internal energies will be uncoordinated, leading to many illnesses. Blindness, deafness, muteness, insanity, and seizures are all due to improper reception of energies.

After a woman conceives, she should not remain in one position for too long while standing, sitting, or lying down, as prolonged actions can harm her muscles and bones; the child in her womb shares energy with the mother, and there will surely be injury. If one engages in excessive passion during intercourse and the child is born with a white membrane on the head, sticky like glue, it is commonly referred to as being born with a "white cap," which is indeed a sign of the connection between mother and child. When a woman is pregnant, her sleeping area should be protected by someone; she should not sleep alone, as evil energies can easily invade; she should avoid dangerous places, fearing she might fall or get hurt.[104p]

Child Fullness

When a pregnant woman reaches seven or eight months, the fetus grows large, the abdomen becomes distended, pressing against the childbirth channel, causing discomfort when sitting or lying down. This condition is called 'child fullness,' and is treated with the Binding the Fetus Decoction.

External Diseases

For a pregnant woman suffering from a sore throat, use the Eastern Garden Cool Diaphragm Powder with one qian of roasted beef seed ground fine. For mouth and tongue ulcers during pregnancy, the Eastern Garden Cool Diaphragm Powder is the primary treatment. Pregnant women often develop breast abscesses; in that case, the Exorcise Toxin Decoction is indicated. If sores or toxins appear on the back, this is related to the Yangming channel. Modify the original formula by removing the green peel and adding one qian each of Cimicifuga and Kudzu root. If sores or toxins appear on the cheeks or chest, this is related to the Shaoyang channel. Modify the original formula by removing the Angelica dahurica and adding Chai Hu, Dan Cao, and Gardenia fruit. For sores or toxins under the shoulder and axilla, which involve the Taiyin channel, remove the green peel from the original formula and add one qian each of dried tangerine peel, Platycodon, mulberry bark, and Asparagus root. For sores or toxins near the inner thighs and genitals, which pertain to the Jueyin channel, remove the Angelica dahurica and double the green peel. For sores or toxins on the palms and soles, concerning the Shaoyin channel, modify the original formula by removing Angelica dahurica, green peel, and Chinese yam powder, and adding one qian each of Huang Lian, Huang Bo, and Mu Tong.

Jingyue's Complete Book

(Ming Dynasty, Zhang Jieben)

Discussions of Men and Women[105p]

When there is a fetus of both genders, there will be distinctions in the timing of its development; when there are both yin and yang, the orientation of the fetus can vary. A male fetus moves at three months, as yang is early; a female fetus moves at five months, as yin is late. A female fetus is positioned with its back to the mother, which is why the mother’s abdomen is soft; a male fetus is positioned facing the mother, resulting in a hard abdomen. This is all based on reason and should be observed.

In general, if the fetal energy during pregnancy is unstable, the causes are not the same, and the treatment should also differ. The instability of fetal energy must have a cause, whether it be deficiency or excess, cold or heat; all can lead to issues with the fetal energy. Eliminating the source of the problem is the method for stabilizing the pregnancy. Therefore, the methods for stabilizing pregnancy should not be rigid, nor should they be limited to specific months; rather, they should be adapted according to the symptoms and conditions presented, treating the ailment with appropriate remedies, which is the best approach. If one considers baizhu and huangqin to be the ultimate remedies for stabilizing pregnancy and insists on using them, it is rarely without error.

If the fetal energy is unstable due to cold, symptoms may include sour regurgitation, nausea and fullness, preference for warmth, and aversion to coolness. Symptoms may also include cold diarrhea, a pulse that is deep and thin, or no heat signs at all while the fetus is unstable, which all denote a deficiency of yang and cold symptoms. To remedy this, one should warm the interior to stabilize the fetus. It is advisable to use warming stomach drinks or formulas that regulate yin, adding or subtracting ingredients as needed. One should also consider the usual condition of the internal organs when deciding on treatment.

If the fetal energy is unstable due to heat, the symptoms will likely include much restlessness and heat, thirst, or agitation, unclear sensations above and below, blood leakage or red urine, or a slippery and rapid pulse among other signs. For these cases, one should primarily use cooling fetal drinks or formulas that nourish yin.[106p]
For those with heat but not deficiency, remedies like Zhiqiao soup, Yimother pills, and Huangqin powder can be selected to clear the heat and stabilize the fetus. In cases where the fetal energy is deficient and unstable, it is particularly challenging to regulate. Here, there are congenital and acquired deficiencies, both of which are critical to the fetal essence. Congenital deficiencies are due to inherited constitution and should be gradually nurtured according to their Yin and Yang tendencies—one must not rush, seeking preservation. Acquired deficiencies arise from human affairs; all forms of desires, fatigue, dietary excesses, and emotional disturbances can harm the fetal essence. The treatment should focus on understanding the underlying causes and adjusting accordingly with caution. Nonetheless, overall, it pertains to the deficiency of blood and Qi, so the focus should be on the Fetal Essence Decoction. If there is deficiency in the heart and spleen Qi, remedies like Xiaoyao drink, Guizhi soup, and Shoupi decoction should be employed. If the liver and kidney are insufficient below, Left and Right Gui drinks should be used, adapting with Yin tonics. In cases where both Qi and blood are deficient, remedies like Wufu drink, Bachen soup, and Shiquan Dabu soup are appropriate. If there is a deficiency of spleen and kidney Qi accompanied by turbidity, remedies like Miyuan decoction and Tusi decoction should be applied. For excessive vomiting and nausea, it is advisable to combine the previously suggested formulas with Erchen decoction to harmonize. In general, when treating deficiency syndromes, flexibility in response is crucial, as there are no absolute rules.[107p]
The presence of excess and stagnant qi can cause discomfort and fullness. This usually arises when the foundational energy is not deficient, but may be obstructed by stagnation. If one observes the causes and addresses them appropriately, treating these issues is not difficult. For persistent vomiting, the Er Chen Decoction with added bitter orange peel and cardamom is effective, or one can use the Ginseng and Tangerine Peel Decoction, which is also excellent. For food stagnation causing fullness and discomfort, the Xiao He Zhong Decoction with modifications is indicated. If liver qi is stagnant, causing reverse flow and discomfort, the Jie Gan Decoction is effective. If anger provokes liver qi along with heat, the Hua Gan Decoction should be used. For spleen and lung qi stagnation resulting in pain, the Zisu Decoction is advisable. If there is qi stagnation with phlegm, the Si Qi Decoction or Er Chen Decoction with added Angelica is suitable. If qi stagnation is accompanied by heat leading to fullness and agitation, the Bitter Orange Decoction or similar remedies should be prescribed. Wang Jiezai said: In caring for pregnant women, it is essential to clear heat and nourish the blood. White Atractylodes tonifies the spleen and is the chief herb for maintaining a stable pregnancy, while the combination with Huang Qin serves as a holy remedy due to its heat-clearing properties, especially during the hot months. This view, while seemingly rational, must be discerned in the face of significant illness. The qi of the fetus must align with the mother's organ qi.[108p]
Generally, those with yin deficiency tend to have excess heat; those with yang deficiency tend to have excess cold. If they can feel cold, they are cold; if they can feel heat, they are hot—this is what we call balanced qi. Now, if we say among ten people, three are cold, three are hot, and four are balanced, this is the general comparison. If one claims that after conception internal heat must increase, differing from ordinary individuals, how can we treat those suffering from adverse conditions without using ingredients like Er Chen San, Liu Jun Zi, fresh ginger, and half summer, which undoubtedly increase heat? Therefore, for treating heat, Huangqin is appropriate, but it is not suitable for cold. Not only is it unsuitable for those who are cold, but also for those with balanced qi. Indeed, among today's pregnant women, there are few with abundant qi and many with qi deficiency. Qi deficiency leads to yang deficiency, and if Huangqin is used again, some may suffer from adverse effects, and even if they do not feel it at the time, it can harm the fetal essence and weaken the mother's qi, resulting in frailty after childbirth or an increase in the child’s spleen-related illnesses, often due to this. Yet, people today cannot perceive this principle but instead regard the phrase "sacred medicine" as essential to use for pregnant women, regardless of an individual's yin or yang strength, believing that all medicines for maintaining pregnancy must be used, which can indeed be quite harmful. As for Baizhu, while it is good for stabilizing pregnancy, it may not always work well if used improperly, due to its nature of being drying and qi-constricting. Therefore, for those with yin deficiency, it should not be used alone, and for those with qi stagnation, it should be used judiciously. Thus, the difficulty in prescribing medicine should be like arranging beads—one cannot be rigid in rules while playing music.[109p]
Aversion to Food

For pregnant women, it is common to experience nausea and vomiting, along with a feeling of fullness and inability to eat. However, the causes of these symptoms vary in nature and should be diagnosed and treated accordingly. Generally, aversion to food is often due to a deficiency in the stomach and qi stagnation. However, it can also occur in women who are not originally deficient but suddenly conceive, resulting in obstruction of the qi from ascending, leading to symptoms like nausea and vomiting. Furthermore, why do these symptoms gradually diminish after three months? This is because, as the fetus grows larger, the energy of the organs is primarily devoted to supporting the fetal energy, thus leaving little room for upward obstructions.

In treating this condition, it is advisable to use formulas like Banxia Fuling Decoction or Renshen Guo Pi Decoction to adjust and gradually calm the situation, ensuring treatment is maintained until the right time for recovery. Fetal Leakage

When a pregnant woman experiences unstable menstrual flow, it is called fetal leakage. The causes of fetal leakage can arise from either fetal energy or pathological energy, and the influences on fetal energy can also be divided into two categories. I once diagnosed a woman whose pulse was slippery and rapid, without any signs of wind-heat or other illnesses. Upon inquiring about her menstrual flow, it appeared mostly normal but slightly reduced compared to before. I concluded that she must be pregnant, as the fetus was small while her blood volume was considerable. After three months, her menstrual flow ceased, and she successfully gave birth to a boy. Therefore, many pregnant women exhibit similar conditions. It is common to see women delivering babies after seven or eight months, but as long as the blood flow stops, it is deemed premature. However, the conception occurred before the flow ceased, which is something people generally do not understand. Even in cases of fetal energy, there are distinctions in the balance of Yin and Yang. If the mother’s energy is strong and the Yin of the fetus is abundant, leading to excess blood overflow, although the blood may leak, the child will not be weak; this illustrates the strength of Yin and does not necessarily require treatment.[112p]
If the paternal Qi is weak and the fetus cannot fully receive it, while there is a loss of blood, it results in both essence and blood being depleted, leading to a child that will inevitably be weak and small; this is a decline of Yang, which is also not well understood by people. All of this originates from the prenatal aspect, where there is nothing that can provide strength. However, nurturing the roots, can it truly have no method of adjustment? It can be seen that the transition from absence to presence and strengthening the weak hands is not easily achieved, making it not something to be discussed lightly. As for losses due to illness, they can only be treated by addressing the illness itself. Sudden Blood Loss

When a woman experiences sudden blood loss during pregnancy, there are four possible conditions: it may be due to heat causing the blood to move abnormally, or due to anger obstructing the qi and stirring the blood, or due to trauma affecting the fetal energy and injuring the uterus, or due to the weakness of the spleen and kidneys leading to instability at the gate of life which causes blood loss. All of these are severe instances of blood movement; if not treated promptly, they will certainly lead to miscarriage.

In addressing this issue, one must first assess the quantity of blood lost and what happens afterward. It is particularly important to examine the severity of the pathological factors. If heat remains, one should still clear the heat; if the qi is not yet harmonized, one should also remedy the qi. If the blood moves due to pathogenic factors and the loss leads to a deficiency of vitality, one must prioritize nourishing the original qi to prevent further loss. Treatment may involve addressing either the symptoms or the root cause, or combining both approaches to restore balance.

If one is unclear about the order of treatment or the urgency, there is a risk that symptomatic treatment will be addressed before the root cause is attended to. Therefore, a thorough investigation is necessary. If the blood movement is caused by intense heat, one must evaluate the degree of heat; if mild, a cooling elixir for the fetus may be given, if slightly more severe, a warming decoction may be appropriate, and if extremely severe, one should use Baoyin Decoction or Ziqin Powder. If the spleen and stomach are inherently weak, or if there is occasional bleeding due to spleen injury, use the Shou Pi Decoction or Gui Pi Decoction; if there is middle Qi sinking, then use the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction. If there is slight heat from blood deficiency and symptoms such as bleeding, use the Xu Duan Decoction. If the blood has already displaced, accumulating in the womb, causing distension and pain, and the remaining blood has not been expelled, wanting to preserve it becomes difficult, while wanting to remove the blood without harming the nutritive Qi requires using Si Wu Decoction with a large dose of Angelica as the most appropriate choice. Miscarriage

A fetus is conceived through the union of the male and female principles, with vital energy flowing and blood following. If nourishment is administered smoothly and in harmony, a birth will occur at the proper time. However, if there are interruptions in this nourishing process, the continuity of its source is disrupted, and the fetus cannot remain secure. This can be likened to someone planting seeds: if the necessary moisture is insufficient, they will wither and fall away. Thus, it is said in the Great Treatise on the Five Constants: what is rooted internally is termed the "spiritual mechanism"; when the spirit departs, the mechanism ceases. What is rooted externally is termed "established energy"; when energy halts, transformation ceases. This is exactly what is meant.

Whenever there are cases of miscarriage during pregnancy, it is always due to the depletion of energy channels. The reasons for this depletion can vary: some individuals may be naturally weak, some may be advanced in age and debilitated, some may suffer from worry, anger, or fatigue that exhausts their vitality, and some may recklessly indulge in desires that harm their life force. Furthermore, external factors like falls or improper diet can also injure these energy channels. If the energy channels are damaged, it is unlikely for a fetus to survive unless it possesses an exceptionally strong and resilient constitution. The average person does not have this capacity.

Moreover, a pregnancy lasts ten months and requires careful nurturing; hence, those who frequently experience miscarriages often do so between the third and fifth or seventh months. Subsequent miscarriages will likely happen similarly at the same intervals because the previous injury to the energy channels renders them incapable of sustaining the pregnancy again at the subsequent time.[117p]
Moreover, a woman’s kidneys are connected to the womb, and the waist is considered the organ of the kidneys. Therefore, pregnant women are particularly prone to back pain; if the pain is severe, it may lead to miscarriage, which cannot be ignored. Thus, those who fear miscarriage must understand the reasons for such injuries and take careful precautions. In treating miscarriages, one must understand the source of nourishing the fetus and proactively compensate for any losses. The methods for preserving pregnancy are fundamentally based on this; waiting until the time is near might leave one without recourse.

In general, an unstable pregnancy stems from damage to the vital energy (qi) and blood. When qi is deficient, it cannot uphold the pregnancy, and when blood is deficient, it fails to nourish properly, often resulting in miscarriages. Therefore, those skilled in preserving pregnancies must focus on addressing blood deficiency, primarily using the Fetal Vitality Decoction and adjusting its components; next is the Peony and Chuanxiong Decoction; then there is the Mount Tai Stone Powder, or the Qianjin Fetal Preservation Pills, both of which have the power to assist natural processes and should be used judiciously.

Additionally, whenever there is heat in the pregnancy, the blood easily becomes agitated. When the blood is in motion, the fetus is unstable, thus it is common for those with internal heat and deficiency to experience this. If one has spleen deficiency and heat in the blood, the Four Saints Powder is recommended. If there is liver and kidney deficiency with blood heat, a Cooling Fetal Drink is suggested. If there is liver and spleen deficiency with blood heat, a Stabilizing Fetus Decoction should be used. Furthermore, if there are other conditions leading to fetal instability, one should refer to the guidelines for pregnancy preservation and treat accordingly.[118p]
Miscarriage

The signs of miscarriage have varying degrees of severity, distance, innate factors, and human circumstances. Those who have innate weaknesses often suffer from miscarriage, while those affected by human circumstances usually experience it due to injury. Natural childbirth arises from the proper readiness of the body, whereas miscarriage results from forced circumstances. This is why miscarriage should not be taken lightly. If a woman is already aging, having borne many children, desiring another pregnancy becomes difficult. In such cases, the priority should be to ensure the mother's health. If a young woman experiences a miscarriage due to carelessness, it is crucial to provide proper care and recovery. Otherwise, if she becomes pregnant again, she may face repeated miscarriages, leading to difficulties in having children, which is a serious concern.[119p]
When women reach middle age and their reproductive energy weakens, they often experience difficulties in carrying a fetus to term and are prone to multiple miscarriages; this occurs due to the deficiency of vital energy and blood. When the vital energy and blood are weakened, after a miscarriage, it is common for the uterus to continue to descend as if there is another fetus wanting to be delivered; this is not actually another fetus but a result of qi deficiency causing the uterus to sag. If the mother is unaware, she will be greatly alarmed. This is not a matter of serious concern; simply using formulas like Shoupi Decoction or Eight Treasures, Ten Fully Nourishing, or Xiong Gui Bu Zhong Decoction will suffice to provide reassurance.

In terms of miscarriages, those occurring in the second or third month are considered close, while those in the fifth or sixth month are seen as distant. Early miscarriages are lighter in impact, while those after a longer duration are heavier; this is well-known. If there are still close cases, they will result in concurrent pregnancies and miscarriages. Among families currently facing difficulties in conceiving, it is estimated that five or six out of ten encounter these issues, primarily due to indulgence in desires.[120p]
However, what has been unknown and disbelieved by people since ancient times, I now cautiously use my pen instead of a lamp to guide those who are lost. If this can benefit future generations, it is my deep wish, so let me explain in detail!

The origin of life begins with the unborn: in the first month, it is like dew on a pearl; in the second month, it resembles peach blossoms. By the third and fourth months, the blood vessels and physical body are formed; in the fifth and sixth months, muscles, bones, and hair begin to grow. At the very beginning, it is merely a drop of original essence — this key to life has no dependency yet, and its roots have no ground. If it is nurtured, it becomes solid; if disturbed, it flows away. Therefore, after conception, it is essential to practice restraint, to prevent overflow. Yet the youth, indulging in their desires, are unaware of taking precautions. Even if the fetus desires to be light and carefree, preserving it remains crucial.[121p]
Some have both courage and strength, relying on their might without defeat, while others, having been defeated, engage in battle again. At such a time, the ruler wishes for tranquility, but the visitor insists on continuing. What can be done about the reckless who pound on doors and walls? Consider the nature of waters that flow with warmth—are there those who do not open the door and instead drift away with the current? At this time, fallen blossoms and powdery butterflies fly together, while fire jujubes and pears intertwine and drift, all merging into the flow, unaware of yesterday's conception and today's birth, as the new moon conceives and the full moon delivers. The process of conception and birth is inherently without visible traces. Indeed, when a birth is evident, the fetus has already taken shape, and a miscarriage must be felt. In contrast, when the birth is obscure, the fetus remains like water, slipping away unnoticed. Thus, among today’s courtesans, many do not have substantial offspring; instead, their many small births become the norm. Those who marry courtesans often have few children, as their wombs are slippery and accustomed to small births. I have seen those who struggle for descendants, when asked about their manly skills, reply that they can battle; when asked about their techniques, they say they excel; but when questioned about their situation, they lament, "Everyone has children but me." Do they not realize that while others bear children clearly, they bear them in secret? Furthermore, for those who conceive and miscarry at three or five months, though this may happen to weak women, it often results from excessive desire and indulgence, which harms the mother’s vitality and leads to miscarriage. Therefore, those who rely on brute strength and excessive bravery often have no children, due to mutual harm between strength and weakness. Likewise, those who indulge without restraint often remain childless, as they deplete the vital energy of the fetus. Can this truly all be blamed on the women?[122p]
The Failure of Fetal Growth

Conversely, overheating blood may impede growth, as excessive fire harms the true yin. For all these conditions, nourishment and strengthening, warmth and clarity should be considered, responding appropriately to the specific ailment; thus, if timed well, growth may occur, or even if delayed, as the fetal essence gradually accumulates, growth will naturally resume. On Pregnancy and Moderation of Desires

Pregnant women should greatly limit their desires. There is much that women may not know, and men also may be ignorant, bordering on foolishness. The strength or weakness of the fetus, the ease or difficulty of childbirth, and the post-natal issues such as hemorrhage and irregularities in the menstrual cycle—all are fundamentally influenced by this. Pregnancy and Cold from the Shaoyin

Prior to the child's birth, one should urgently use the Revival of Yang Decoction; after the child is born, one should urgently use Zhongjing's formula.

If a pregnant woman is about to give birth and suddenly feels symptoms of the Shaoyin channel, she should urgently use a large dose of Ren Shen and Bai Zhu to warm her; if it does not respond, it may lead to death, as stated in Zhongjing's texts. It seems that without Ren Shen and Bai Zhu, there are no other effective medicines. I believe that using only Ren Shen and Bai Zhu may not be completely reliable. If they do not respond, one should urgently add Fu Zi, Rou Gui, and Gan Jiang; it may well respond immediately.

Now, I have established a formula called the Complete Lifesaving Decoction: 2 taels of Ren Shen, 2 taels of Bai Zhu, 1 qian of Fu Zi, 5 fen of Gan Cao, brewed in water for consumption. For any illness caused by the Shaoyin channel, this formula has miraculous effects.[132p]
Fang

Four Substance Decoction: This is used to treat various ailments in women related to pregnancy and childbirth. Frequently, this decoction is adjusted based on individual needs. The ingredients include Rehmannia, Chuanxiong, Peony, and Dong Quai, with specifics on adding and reducing later.

The right side (口父) indicates to take it as a decoction after grinding. For adjustments: if there is abdominal pain during pregnancy with bleeding, fetal movement is unsettled, or postpartum issues such as excessive lochia or retention, the Four Substance Decoction should be supplemented with dried evodia. If the patient has excess Yang, use less dried evodia; if Yang is deficient, use more.

For unsettled fetal movement with persistent bleeding during pregnancy, the Four Substance Decoction should be combined with ten leaves of mugwort, one slice of donkey-hide gelatin, or include scallions and astragalus. Alternatively, add five to seven leaves of mugwort during each dose, along with scallions and half the amount of donkey-hide gelatin, using a smaller half dose of Dong Quai.

In severe cases, grind all four ingredients down to evenly sized pieces, using four cups of water, a piece of dried mugwort the size of a chicken egg, and five to seven slices of donkey-hide gelatin. Boil until down to two and a half cups, dividing it into four doses to be taken within a day. You can also add powdered licorice, dried ginger, and astragalus, taking two to three doses daily, until the second lunar month, treating one week as a lunar period.

If there is restlessness during pregnancy, add a piece of bamboo shavings to the Four Substance Decoction.[133p]
During pregnancy, if there is a tendency for evil influences, causing a cold face and a pallor, with no desire for food, resulting in emaciation, one may take a decoction of Four Substance Soup with dried tangerine peel, bitter orange, white atractylodes, poria, and licorice.

If there is damage to the fetus leading to persistent bleeding, headache, alternating chills and fever, and tinnitus due to exhaustion of qi and blood, one should take Four Substance Soup with scutellaria, schizonepeta, raw rehmannia, red peony, and ginger.

If fetal movement is accompanied by continuous bleeding, one can take Four Substance Soup with astragalus, cedar, ejiao, licorice, and dang gui.

For calming the fetus and managing bleeding, add ejiao, mugwort, licorice, and prepared pollen to Four Substance Soup.

In cases of small intestine qi pain during conception, Four Substance Soup can be supplemented with musk and fennel.

For coughing during pregnancy, add bitter orange, licorice, winter flower, anemarrhena, aristolochia, pinellia, mutong, vine, ginseng, platycodon, and ophiopogon to Four Substance Soup.

If fetal qi conflicts with the liver, causing weakness in the waist and legs, making movement difficult, use Four Substance Soup with bitter orange, mutong, licorice, forsythia, schizonepeta, rehmannia, dhaturo, and gardenia, to be taken on an empty stomach.

For women before giving birth, Four Substance Soup can be taken once or twice daily.

If there is dysentery after labor, accompanied by wind, one can use Four Substance Soup with frankincense, dragon bone, evodia, musk, cinnamon, white atractylodes, peony bark, white snail, ginseng, licorice, saussurea, and fennel.[134p]
Jiao Ai Decoction, also known as Qiong Gui Jiao Ai Decoction. It is used to treat abdominal pain during pregnancy, obstruction of the womb and fetal leakage, continued bleeding after childbirth, and hemorrhage in the eighth or ninth month. The ingredients are:

  • Chuanxiong
  • Fried Ejiao
  • Honey-fried Licorice, each 2 taels
  • Fried Ai Ye
  • Dang Gui, each 3 taels
  • Bai Shao Yao, 4 taels
  • Dry Di Huang.

Combine these seven ingredients with 5 sheng of water and 3 sheng of clear rice wine, boil down to 3 sheng, strain out the dregs, and dissolve the Ejiao in the mixture. Warm the decoction and take 1 sheng, three times a day. Alternatively, take half a tael each time, boiled in water. One variation adds 1 tael of dried ginger. Hu Qia suggests a formula for fetal movement in women without dried ginger. Another variation includes Huang Qi.

Dang Gui Powder is taken regularly during pregnancy to facilitate childbirth. It addresses any pain in the fetus, postpartum ailments, weakened qi and blood, stagnant lochia, and symptoms of cold and fever. For those who are prone to complications during childbirth, regular consumption is advisable to clear the source of these issues, preventing future problems.

The ingredients consist of:

  • Dang Gui (main)
  • Huang Qin, stir-fried with wine
  • Bai Shao Yao
  • Chuanxiong, each 1 jin
  • Bai Zhu, 0.5 jin.

Crush these into a powder, mix with wine, and take a spoonful twice daily. Alternatively, mix with wine to form pills, taking 50 to 70 pills with rice drink. Another version includes 1 tael each of Dang Gui, Bai Shao, Chuanxiong, and Huang Qin, with 5 qian of Bai Zhu, ground into a powder, and mixed with 2 qian of child's urine for ingestion.[135p]
Bai Zhu Powder: For nourishing the fetus during pregnancy.
Bai Zhu and Xiong Huang, each one liang; Shu Jiao, seven qian, remove sweat; Mu Li, half a liang. Grind these into a powder. Take one qian with wine, three times a day, and once at night. If there is bitter pain, add Shao Yao; if there is toxic pain under the heart, double the amount of Xiong Huang; if there is irritability with vomiting and inability to eat or drink, add one liang of Xi Xin and twenty large Ban Xia. Afterward, take it with vinegar water. If the vinegar water does not resolve the issue, take with wheat juice. If you feel thirsty afterward, take barley porridge. Even after recovery, continue taking.

Gui Zhi Fu Ling Pill: For women with lingering symptoms during pregnancy, particularly those experiencing continuous bleeding and fetal movement above the navel within the first three months.
Gui Zhi, Fu Ling, Mu Dan, peach kernel (skin and tip removed), and Shao Yao—grind these five ingredients into equal portions. Refine with honey to form pills the size of rabbit droppings. Take one pill before each meal. If the condition is unknown, increase to three pills. This prescription is highly praised by Dan Xi.

Xuan Fu Hua Decoction (from the "Thousand Gold Formula", same hereafter): For women who experience abnormal pulses and leaking after childbirth.
Three liang of Xuan Fu Hua, fourteen stalks of scallion, and a small amount of Xin Jiang.
Boil these three ingredients in three sheng of water to reduce it to one sheng, and take it in one dose.[136p]
Dan Shen Yuan: This treats women who begin to feel pregnant, nurturing the fetus and transforming a female child into a male. Ingredients: Dan Shen, Xu Duan, Shao Yao, Bai Jiao, Bai Zhu, Bai Zi Ren, Gan Cao - each 2 taels; Ren Shen, Chuan Xiong, Gan Jiang - each 30 zhú; Wu Zhu Yu, Ju Pi, Dang Gui - each 1 tael 18 zhús; Bai Zhi, Guan Ying Hui - each 1 tael; Gan Di Huang 1.5 taels; Wu Yi 18 zhús; a dog’s egg one; a male chicken head from the east gate one. Grind to a fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of a walnut. Take 10 pills with wine, twice daily, gradually increasing to 20 pills.

Ju Pi Tang: This treats vomiting during pregnancy that prevents eating. Ingredients: Ju Pi, Zhu Ru, Ren Shen, Bai Zhu (stir-fried), each 18 zhús; Sheng Jiang 1 tael; Hou Po 12 zhús. Grind, take 7 sheng of water, boil to get 2.5 sheng, divide into three doses; if it does not improve, repeat.

Wu Ci Ji Tang: This treats abdominal pain from cold during the first month of pregnancy, severe heat causing sudden shock, heavy lifting causing lower back pain, abdominal fullness, and urgent contractions. Ingredients: One female black chicken treated as food; Fu Ling, E Jiao - each 2 taels; Wu Zhu Yu 1 sheng; Mai Men Dong 5 he; Ren Shen, Shao Yao, Bai Zhu - each 3 taels; Gan Cao, Sheng Jiang - each 1 tael. Grind, use 12 sheng of water to boil the chicken, extract 6 sheng of liquid, remove the chicken, add the herbs, boil to obtain 3 sheng, dissolve 3 sheng of wine and E Jiao, and take 3 sheng warm, 1 sheng three times a day.[137p]
Bump Tire Decoction: For those who have experienced a miscarriage in the first month of pregnancy, this medicine should be taken in advance.

  • Xi Xin (Asarum) 1 tael
  • Fang Feng (Siler) 2 taels
  • Gan Di Huang (Rehmannia) 2 taels
  • Bai Zhu (Atractylodes) 2 taels
  • Sheng Jiang (Fresh Ginger) 4 taels
  • Wu Zhu Yu (Evodia) 5 hyoscyamus
  • Da Mai (Barley) 5 hyoscyamus
  • Wu Mei (Mume) 1 sheng

Prepare by grinding the above ingredients and boil with 7 sheng of water to obtain 2 sheng. Divide into three doses, taking it after eating. If there is excess cold, double the Xi Xin and Wu Zhu Yu; if there is a lot of heat or thirst, omit them and add 2 taels of Lu Gen (Reed Root). If there is any concern, remove the barley and add 3 hyoscyamus of Bai Zi Ren (Platycladus Seed). One recipe includes 1 tael of Ren Shen (Ginseng).

Mugwort Decoction: Treats those in the second month of pregnancy where there is a blockage of Yin and Yang, with significant cold leading to miscarriage, or heat causing withering; sudden onset of wind-cold can lead to movement, causing fullness in the heart with urgent pain below the navel, strong pain in the waist and back, sudden chills and heat.

  • Ai Ye (Mugwort) 2 taels
  • Dan Shen (Salvia) 2 taels
  • Dang Gui (Angelica) 2 taels
  • Ma Huang (Ephedra) 2 taels
  • Sheng Jiang (Fresh Ginger) 6 taels
  • Ren Shen (Ginseng) 3 taels
  • E Jiao (Donkey-hide Gelatin) 3 taels
  • Gan Cao (Licorice) 4 fen
  • Da Zao (Jujube) 12 pieces

Prepare by grinding the ingredients, then boil with 3 sheng of wine and 1 dou of water, reducing to half and straining. Dissolve the gelatin and take the remaining 3 sheng divided into three doses.[138p]
Huanglian Decoction
For those who have previously hurt a two-month fetus during pregnancy, this medicine should be taken in advance.
Huanglian: 1 liang
Ren Shen: 1 liang
Wuzhuyu: 5 he
Shengjiang: 3 liang
Sheng Dihuang: 5 liang
Mince the above (all ingredients), use 7 sheng of vinegar to boil and extract 3 sheng, divide into four doses, taking three times a day and once at night, for ten days for continuous use. If feeling unsettled, add 1 sheng of Wumei, then do not use vinegar but simply boil with water. An alternative prescription uses 0.5 liang of Donggui, and another uses Ejiao.

Rooster Decoction
For stabilizing a pregnancy at three months, it treats cold with dark stools and heat with difficult urination; if not red then yellow, sudden fright, anxiety, anger, happiness, and fainting; moving within the meridians, fullness in the abdomen with pain around the navel, or back pain with sudden expulsion.
One rooster, prepared like food,
Shaoyao: 4 liang
Huangqin, Baizhu, Shengjiang: each 1 liang
Maidong: 5 he
Dazao: 12 pieces
Gancao, Ren Shen, Fuling, Ejiao: each 2 liang
Mince the above, boil the chicken in 13 sheng of water, reduce by half, extract half the liquid with the medicine, add 3 sheng of clear wine, and simmer to extract another 3 sheng, divide into three doses to finish in one day, and rest warmly. One alternative uses 2 liang each of Donggui and Chuanxiong, omitting Huangqin and Shengjiang.[139p]
Fuzhen Decoction: For those who have previously suffered a miscarriage at three months during pregnancy, this medicine should be taken in advance. Chrysanthemum Decoction: Treats cold in the fourth month of pregnancy, with a warm feeling under the heart, a desire to vomit, fullness in the chest with no appetite, difficulty urinating with heat, frequent discomfort resembling painful urination, bitterness and urgency below the navel, sudden wind-cold with stiff neck and pain, alternating chills and fever, or unexpected bodily agitation, along with back and abdominal pain at times, and pressure from the fetus on the chest, causing anxiety without rest. Ingredients: One large egg of chrysanthemum, 1 sheng of Mai Men Dong, 12 Dazao, 1.5 taels of Renshen, 2 taels each of Gancao and Danggui, 3 taels each of Mahuang and Ejiao, 4 taels of Banxia, 5 taels of fresh ginger. Tiaozhong Decoction: For those who have had a miscarriage in the fourth month of pregnancy, this medicine should be taken in advance. Ejiao Decoction: For treating symptoms in the fifth month of pregnancy including heat, bitter headaches, dizziness, chaotic heart, nausea, abdominal fullness and pain, frequent urination, sudden fear, limb pain, alternating cold and heat, foetal movement abnormalities, abdominal pain leading to collapse, and sudden discharge. Ingredients include: four liang of ejiao, one liang of ginseng, six liang of fresh ginger, two liang each of angelica, white peony, licorice, and scutellaria; two he of reversed flower; seven he of evodia; and two sheng of ophiopogon. Divide this into four doses, to be taken three times during the day and once at night. Take this after food for recovery. If not healed, take again.[141p]

Scallion White Decoction: Treats sudden scares, shaking, abdominal pain, unexpected discharge, cold hands and feet, weak pulse, feelings of heat and abdominal fullness, shortness of breath, often suffering from stiff neck and lower back during the seventh month of pregnancy.

Peony Soup: For treating wind-cold in the eighth month of pregnancy, after an incident, with the whole body in pain, alternating between cold and heat, unable to be still, bitter head pain circling below the navel, frequent urination that is white like rice juice, or blue or yellow, or experiencing chills, with low back pain and cold, distorted vision. Banxia Decoction: Treats nine months of pregnancy, when suddenly experiencing diarrhea, a feeling of fullness and urgency in the abdomen, the fetus pushing upwards against the heart, back pain, difficulty turning, and shortness of breath.

Dan Shen Paste: This paste nurtures the fetus. It is taken in the last month of pregnancy, facilitating smooth delivery. Ingredients: 0.5 jin of Dan Shen, 0.2 jin each of Chuanxiong and Danggui, 0.5 sheng of Shu Pepper. Once it is done, strain it through a new cloth; take a portion daily the size of a jujube and mix it with wine to consume. It should not be taken backwards, only during the last month, as has been traditionally verified. An alternative: for those with heat, use 0.5 sheng of hemp seeds instead of Shu Pepper.

Licorice Powder: Facilitates childbirth and ensures the mother remains healthy. Begin taking it one month prior to the expected delivery date. After thirty days, continue regular activities; when the child is born, it will happen without any awareness. Recipe for Producing Treasures: To treat unprovoked fetal movements and abdominal cramping during pregnancy.

Essential Recipe for Nurturing Life: To treat pain in the lower back and abdomen caused by fetal movement.

Ingredients:

  • 2 qian of Ejiao
  • 2 qian of Ligusticum
  • 2 qian of Angelica
  • 2 qian of Green Bamboo Shoots

Preparation:

  1. Boil with 10 cups of water and 1 jin of silver until 5 cups remain.
  2. Remove the silver, add the three medicinal ingredients, and boil until 2.5 cups remain.
  3. Strain, add the gelatin, and reboil until dissolved.
  4. Divide into three warm doses to be taken on an empty stomach from morning until evening. If ineffective, prepare again.

Mistletoe Decoction: To treat unsettled fetal energy, especially after five months of pregnancy.

Ingredients:

  • 0.5 tael of washed Mulberry Mistletoe
  • 0.5 tael of Gentian
  • 0.5 tael of Ejiao
  • 0.5 tael of Glutinous Rice Flour

Preparation:

  1. Use 3 sheng of fresh spring water, first adding mistletoe and gentian, and boil down to 2 sheng; then strain.
  2. Next, add the Ejiao and glutinous rice flour, boiling until about 1 sheng remains.
  3. Divide into three doses to be taken on an empty stomach before meals, particularly at noon.

Avoid alcohol and vinegar for three to five days. Pregnant women with unstable fetal energy after five months will find this effective. If a pregnant woman craves alcohol or eats sour, salty, or pungent foods, fetal movement will surely occur, which should be duly noted.[147p]

Diao Teng Decoction: For restless fetal movement during the eighth or ninth month of pregnancy, abdominal pain, pale face, cold sweat, and near fainting; this is due to labor straining the fetal womb and should be treated urgently.
Bitter stem one and a half liang, half a liang of Sang Ji Sheng, Diao Teng hook, Angelica, Fu Shen, and Ginseng, each one liang. Grind these to a coarse powder, take five large qian with two cups of water, boil down to one cup, strain and take warm at any time. Avoid pork and kale. If there’s heat, add two and a half liang of gypsum; if in the month before childbirth, add one liang of cinnamon heart.[149p]
Fetal Protection Formula
For treating unstable fetal movements during pregnancy.
Two pounds of carp, one liter of glutinous rice, one handful of scallions, some fermented soybeans, fresh ginger. Prepare as soup and consume once a month.

Iron Cover Powder for Fetal Stability
Highly effective for stabilizing pregnancy.
One tael of white peony root, half a tael of white atractylodes. Grind into fine powder. Take two qian with a decoction of purple perilla. If there is heart heat and restlessness, add a little sand sugar while boiling.
Also, there is a formula for treating inability to turn during pregnancy.
One tael of processed donkey-hide gelatin, half a tael of mulberry mistletoe. Grind into powder, then use one liter of wine, boil five times, add one raw chicken egg into the wine, divide into two warm doses before meals. The "Minor Prescription" does not include mistletoe, only uses mugwort leaves and is boiled with water.

Carp Soup Formula
For treating unstable fetal movements and heartburn during pregnancy.
One pound of carp, trimmed and finely chopped, one tael of donkey-hide gelatin, crushed and roasted until yellow, two he of glutinous rice. Combine these with two liters of water, add the fish, gelatin, and rice, cook until done, then add scallion whites, fresh ginger, tangerine peel, and a little salt, boil for an additional five to seven times before eating. For injuries, consume for five to seven days before seeing effects.

Complete Formula
For treating sudden appearance of yellow juice like glue or bean juice, fetal movement and abdominal pain during pregnancy.
Five he of glutinous rice, six taels of astragalus root.[150p]
Take seven sheng of water, boil down to two sheng, and divide into four doses.

Another formula treats pain all over during pregnancy, or if there is a sensation of impending death, with inability to eat or drink.

Five taels of white atractylodes, two taels of huangqin, and four taels of peony.

Take six sheng of water, boil down to two and a half sheng, and divide into three doses. This is because pain during pregnancy can be caused by water, which also facilitates childbirth.

Danggui Decoction, also known as Baoan Powder, treats restlessness of the fetus, severe anguish in the heart, irritability, dry mouth, abnormal fetal positioning leading to distress, with lips and mouth appearing dark blue, and cold extremities.

One tael each of danggui, fried ejiao, and licorice; one and a half taels of ginseng; and a handful of green onion roots.

Grind these ingredients, use two sheng of water, and decoct them until reduced to one and a half sheng. Strain, add the green onion again, and decoct a second time until reduced to three he, and serve warm in two or three doses. There is a variant without licorice, using川芎 (Chuanxiong) and houpo instead.

For leakage during pregnancy, treat with yellow juice leakage, or like bean juice.

Two cups of fresh mugwort juice, one tael each of ejiao and white honey; decoct to seven-tenths and serve warm. If fresh mugwort is unavailable, use concentrated juice from dried mugwort instead. There is a variant that adds bamboo shavings. Another variant uses wine without honey.

Another formula for abdominal pain and occasional bleeding during the third or fourth month of pregnancy consists of:

Two taels of xu duan, six taels each of mugwort leaves, danggui, and dried rehmannia root; one tael each of bamboo shavings, ejiao, and chicken's foot.

Use one sheng of water and decoct to six he, then take it on an empty stomach.[151p]
Jishengru Shengtang is used to treat fetal movement and abdominal pain, which may indicate fetal flooding. The ingredients are as follows: carp fish skin, soaked in Angelica wine; cooked Rehmannia, steamed with wine; white peony; and fried Ejiao with clam powder; Chuanxiong; and Du Huo, soaked in wine; and licorice, toasted, all in equal parts. Take four qian per dose, simmered in one cup of water with a small amount of ramie root and five slices of ginger, and take it warm. Another formula includes dried ginger and bamboo shavings.

Sangjisheng San is used to treat fetal flooding with irregular bleeding, continuing unabated. The ingredients include: Sangjisheng, Angelica (removed from its leaves) soaked in wine; Chuanxiong; Du Huo soaked in wine; fried Ejiao with clam powder; fried Xiangfuzi (fennel) after removing the hairs; foxtail, from which wood is removed; and Bai Zhu (white atractylodes), each one qian; Ren Shen (ginseng) and ginger, each five fen. Combine these to make one dose, boil in two cups of water with five slices of ginger until reduced to one cup, and can be taken any time.

Zheng's Ginseng Powder treats fetal flooding with blood stasis in the heart, gradually leading to a dry fetus, putting both mother and child in danger. The ingredients include: ginseng, toasted Huangqi (astragalus); fried Ejiao with clam powder, each five qian; bamboo shavings; wood incense; roasted licorice; and Fuzi (aconite), prepared by removing skin and navel, each half a qian; Chuanxiong, Chen Pi (tangerine peel), and ramie root, each two and a half qian; fresh ginger, three qian, roasted dark. Take four qian per dose, mixed with thirty glutinous rice grains, and boil in water to drink hot. Avoid raw, cold, chicken, duck, fish, and noodles.[152p]
Er Huang San: For treating fetal movement.
Mix raw and cooked Rehmannia in equal parts, grind. Add three cups of water, decoct until half dry, strain and take.

Dan Xi Fang: For blood clots like a disc; during pregnancy, strong agents are difficult to take. This formula is for that.
Cook Xiangfuzi in vinegar, four taels; Bai Zhu, Tao Ren (peeled and pointed), each one tael; Hai Fen cooked in vinegar, two taels. Grind into a powder and form into pills with flour.

Bu Yi An Tai San: For sudden lower back pain and continuous bleeding.
Combine cooked Rehmannia, Ai Ye (mugwort), Bai Shao (white peony), Chuan Xiong, Huang Qi (astragalus), Dong Gui (angelica), stir-fried E Jiao (donkey-hide gelatin), Gan Cao (licorice), and Di Yu (sanguisorba), all in equal parts. Each dose is four qian, with five slices of ginger and one jujube, decoct and take while warm.

Xiong Gui Tang: For dealing with cold symptoms during pregnancy, sudden abdominal pain like a knife.
Combine Chuan Xiong, Ren Shen (ginseng), Bai Fu Ling (white poria), Wu Zhu Yu (evodia), Ku Guo (bitter orange), and Dong Gui, each three taels; Hou Po (magnolia bark) and Shao Yao (peony), each two taels. Grind together, use nine sheng (liters) of water, boil down to three sheng, divide into three doses; if qi descends, relief is achieved.

Cao Dou Kou San: For pregnant women with constant abdominal pain, reduced appetite, and limbs feeling weak, unable to eat.
Combine Cao Dou Kou, Ju Pi (tangerine peel), raw Rehmannia, Bai Zhu, each one tael; stir-fried Dong Gui, Gui Xin (cinnamon), Gan Jiang (dried ginger), and Mu Xiang (aurantium wood), each half a tael; Chuan Xiong seven qian and five fen. Grind into a fine powder; for each dose, four qian mixed with one cup of water and two jujubes, decoct until six portions remain, take hot.[153p]
Rehmannia and Angelica Decoction: Treats pregnant women with abdominal pain due to deficiency in the Chong and Ren vessels, suitable for suppressing Yang and assisting Yin.

  • Angelica: 1 liang
  • Cooked Rehmannia: 2 liang
    Grind these into a powder, prepare one dose with 3 sheng of water, simmer until reduced to 1.5 sheng, strain and consume immediately. A variation involves slightly toasting the mixture, then forming pills the size of walnuts. Take 30 to 50 pills with warm wine, called Inner Nourishing Pills.

Acanthopanax Powder: Treats unbearable lower back pain during pregnancy, possibly extending to the legs; first, take this powder.

  • Cooked Eucommia: 4 liang (stripped of fibers)
  • Acanthopanax
  • Ejiao (donkey-hide gelatin, toasted)
  • Ledebouriella
  • Golden Hair Dog Spine
  • Chuanxiong
  • Peony
  • Asarum
  • Alisma: 3 liang each
  • Almonds: 80 pieces, skin removed and toasted
    Grind together as directed, using 9 sheng of water, boil to obtain 2 sheng, strain, add the gelatin, and divide into three doses. Afterward, take the Acanthopanax Pills. One variation includes white Poria without white Peony.

Acanthopanax Pills

    Bai Zhu (4 qian), Chen Pi (3 qian), Huang Bo (stir-fried, 2.5 qian), Ren Shen, Diao Qin, Chuan Xiong, Di Huang, Gui Wei (each 0.5 liang), Gan Cao (frizzled, 1 qian).

The above is divided into four doses, to be decocted in water and wine for oral administration.

Da Di Huang Wan treats pre- and postpartum lower back and abdominal pain, and all kinds of pain related to the blood; it also addresses blood and Qi deficiency, weakness in the limbs, and bone marrow heat pain.

Shu Di Huang (2 liang), Wu Mei flesh, Dang Gui (each 1 liang).

The above should be ground into a fine powder, refined into honey to make pills the size of ball bearings, and each time, one pill should be chewed and swallowed with warm white soup on an empty stomach.

Xiao Pin Zhu Gen Tang treats damage to the fetus, lower back and abdominal pain, and expels blood leading to downward fetal movement.

Sheng Gan Di Huang, Zhu Gen (each 2 liang), Dang Gui, Shao Yao, A Jiao, and Gan Cao (each 1 liang).

Cut finely, use 6 sheng of water, boil to obtain 2 sheng, discard the dregs, add the gelatin, and dissolve. Divide into three warm doses. Avoid seaweed and bitter herbs.

Cang Gong Xia Qi Tang treats pregnancy-related abdominal distension, obstruction in the sides, inability to eat, and weakness in the limbs.

Qiang Huo, Chi Shao Yao, Gan Cao, Bin Lang, Qing Pi, Da Fu Pi, Chen Pi, Chi Fu Ling, Ban Xia, Sang Bai Pi, Gui Xin (each 0.5 liang), Zi Su stem (2 liang).

The above should be chewed, and each dose (3 qian) should be prepared with 1 cup of water, 5 slices of ginger, and 1 jujube, boiled until reduced by half, then dregged and consumed whenever needed. For certain syndromes, the formula may vary slightly, adding Deng Xin decoction.[155p]
An Tai He Qi Decoction treats cold in the womb causing abdominal distension, pain radiating to both sides, frequent urination, and loose stools.

Ingredients:

  • 3 pieces of baked hawthorn (without seeds)
  • 6 grams of white atractylodes
  • Dried tangerine peel (white part removed)
  • 3 grams of high-quality ginger (stir-fried)
  • 3 grams of honey-fried licorice

Preparation: Combine the above ingredients to make one dose, add two cups of water and five slices of fresh ginger, and simmer until it reduces to one cup. Take at any time, avoiding raw and cold foods.

Zhi Ke Decoction treats abdominal distension in pregnant women.

Ingredients:

  • 180 grams of bitter orange
  • 60 grams of scutellaria

Preparation: Grind into a coarse powder, take 15 grams each time, simmer with half a cup of water and consume warm. If there is excessive fullness in the abdomen and heaviness, add 30 grams of white atractylodes.

Tian Xian Teng Powder treats swelling and fullness during pregnancy.

Ingredients:

  • Tian Xian Teng (Chinese climbing fern), slightly washed and stir-fried
  • Cyperus rotundus (stir-fried)
  • Dried tangerine peel
  • Licorice
  • Lindera aggregata

Preparation: Mix these in equal parts to a fine powder, take 9 grams each time, simmer with one large cup of water, three slices of ginger, three slices of papaya, and three leaves of perilla until reduced to seven-tenths, cool and strain. Consume on an empty stomach three times a day. It helps relieve urination, unblocks qi pathways, and reduces swelling gradually.

Qian Jin Li Yu Soup treats abdominal swelling with water accumulation during pregnancy.

Ingredients:

  • 250 grams of white atractylodes
  • 160 grams of poria
  • 90 grams of angelica
  • 90 grams of peony

Preparation: Chop finely and prepare one whole carp as per the cooking method, extract the juice and discard the fish. Take 15 grams each time and mix with one and a half cups of fish juice, seven slices of fresh ginger, and a small amount of dried tangerine peel, simmer until reduced to seven-tenths, strain and consume on an empty stomach.[156p]
Collection of Medical Works, Volume 387 - Treatise on Women's Pre-pregnancy

Formulas

Muxiang Pills: For treating pregnant women with food-related injuries.

  • Ingredients: 2 qian of Muxiang, 3 qian each of Sanleng, Ginseng, and Bai Fuling.
  • Preparation: Grind finely and form into pills the size of a broad bean. Swallow 30-40 pills with warm water.

Baizhu Powder: For regulating stomach qi in pregnant women, where diet is easily affected.

  • Ingredients: 1 liang of fried Baizhu, 1 liang of Zi Su, 7.5 qian each of Ginseng and Bai Zhi, 0.5 liang each of Chuanxiong, Hezi peel, and Qingpi, and 2.5 qian of Licorice.
  • Preparation: Grind into powder, and take 2 qian with a cup of water, and 3 slices of ginger, decoct until reduced to 70%, and consume warm.

Zhengshi Shengjin Powder: For pregnant women suffering from the effects of food, leading to spleen and stomach issues, with qi deficiency causing coldness, resulting in lower abdominal distension and pain, or heavy waist, and constipation.

  • Ingredients: 1.5 qian each of Wu Zhu Yu soaked in wine, Chen Pi, dried Ginger pounded, sliced and toasted Ginger, and Chuanxiong, and 3 qian each of honey-fried Licorice and thick skin prepared with ginger.
  • Preparation: Grind finely and take 3 qian, consuming with Chen rice drink. It is particularly effective when simmered with salt. “Jisheng Fang” adds sand cardamom.[157p]
    Shengxi Jiao San: Used to treat sudden stroke during pregnancy causing inability to speak. Symptoms include rigidity in limbs and confusion.

  • Shengxi Jiao (fresh rhinoceros horn powder) - a dose of 1 tael.

Bai Jiang Can San: Used to treat stroke during pregnancy leading to locked jaw, blocked phlegm and saliva, inability to speak, and rigidity in limbs.

  • Huo Xiang (agastache) - 0.5 tael.
    Preparation: Make into fine powder, mix thoroughly, each dose is 1 qian, stir with fresh ginger and mint soup, anytime, three times a day.

Chi Jian Wan: Used to treat stroke during pregnancy, causing unresponsive hands and feet, tense or relaxed meridians, speech difficulty, and numb skin.
Ingredients:

  • Chi Jian (red arrow),
  • Bi Xie (herb) - soaked in wine,
  • Ma Huang (astragalus without joints) - 1.5 taels,
  • Du Huo - 1 tael,

    Bai Zhu Wine: Treats gestational stroke causing mouth tightness and inability to speak. Use one and a half taels of Bai Zhu, one tael of Du Huo, and one handful of black beans, stir-fried. Grind fine, add three sheng of wine, decoct to one and a half sheng, strain, and divide into four doses. For those with a tight mouth, force-feed it; sweating will lead to recovery.

Ling Yang Jiao San: Treats gestational anxiety and confusion, with a condition referred to as fetal convulsion. Use ground antelope horn, Du Huo, stir-fried sour jujube seed, Wu Jia Pi, Fang Feng, stir-fried Coix seed, Angelica soaked in wine, Chuan Xiong, peeled apricot kernel, and Fu Ling, each five fen; and Mu Xiang and honey-fried Licorice, each two fen. Decoct with ginger water.

Qiang Huo Wine: Treats gestational stroke symptoms including mouth tightness, strong limbs, and arched back. Use one and a half taels of Qiang Huo, one tael of Fang Feng, and one handful of black beans, stir-fried to remove the skin. Mix these three ingredients, steep in five sheng of fine wine overnight. For each dose, use one handful of black beans, stir-fry until cooked, add to a large cup of medicinal wine, bring to a boil, remove the dregs, and divide into two doses for administration.

Da Sheng San: Treats gestational palpitations, frequent fright during sleep, abdominal and lateral swelling, and discomfort in sitting or lying down. Use one and a half qian each of white Fu Ling, Mai Men Dong, honey-fried Huang Qi, Angelica soaked in wine, and Chuan Xiong; and one qian each of Mu Xiang, Ren Shen, and honey-fried Licorice. Prepare as a single dose, using two sheng of water and five slices of fresh ginger, decoct until reduced to one sheng, to be taken at any time.[159p]
Mai Men Dong Decoction: Treats anxiety during pregnancy, fear, and irritability, known as "Zi Fan."
Ingredients: Mai Men Dong, Bai Fu Ling, Fang Feng, each 9 grams; Ren Shen, 4.5 grams.
Preparation: Combine and boil with 480 ml of water, add 5 slices of fresh ginger and 10 leaves of thin bamboo. Simmer until reduced to 240 ml. Strain and consume at any time.

Mai Men Dong Powder: Treats irritability during pregnancy, mental confusion, restlessness, vomiting, aversion to food smells, dizziness, heaviness in limbs, joint pain, and reduced movement.
Ingredients: Mai Men Dong, Zi QIn, Chi Fu Ling, each 30 grams; Sheng Di, 22.5 grams; Ren Shen, Fu Shen, Chi Shao Yao, Chen Pi, Ku Geng, Sang Ji Sheng, Gan Cao, Xuan Fu Hua, each 15 grams.
Preparation: Grind into a coarse powder. Take 12 grams each time, boil with 240 ml of water and 3 grams of ginger until reduced to 180 ml. Strain and drink warm at any time.

Ren Shen Powder: Treats heat from pregnancy affecting the heart and spleen, with dry and sparse fluids, irritability, and excessive heat and thirst.
Ingredients: Ren Shen, Mai Men Dong, Chi Fu Ling, Di Gu Pi, Jia Gan Ge, Huang Qin, Xi Jiao Xie, each 22.5 grams; Gan Cao, 15 grams.
Preparation: Chop and grind. Take 9 grams each time, boil with 240 ml of water until reduced to 180 ml. Strain and drink warm.[160p]

Treats discomfort in pregnancy caused by medication leading to fetal anxiety, resembling restlessness and inability to sleep, known as "zi fan."

Ma Dou Ling San
Treats stagnation of fetal energy during pregnancy, causing cough and urgent breathing.

Chai Hu Yin: Treats malaria during pregnancy.

Jia Wei Li Zhong Tang: Treats deficiency cold diarrhea.

Zhu Ling San: Treats painful urination in pregnancy and related water retention.
Ingredients: Zhu Ling 5 liang, peel removed.
Preparation: Grind into powder, mix with white water using 2 dabs, take 3 times a day and 2 times at night. If not cured, a downward movement with a previous herb may be necessary.[162p]
Sunflower Seed Soup: For treating pregnancy-related illnesses lasting over six or seven days, with body heat entering the organs, and difficulty in urination and defecation. It calms the fetus and eliminates heat.

Take two sheng of sunflower seeds and four ounces of talcum, crushed. Boil these with five sheng of water until one sheng remains, strain, and take it all at once; immediate relief will follow.

Another Recipe: For addressing difficulty in urination and defecation during pregnancy, along with abdominal distension causing discomfort, lack of appetite, and hot hands and feet.

Ingredients: Areca nut, red Poria, large abdominal peel, and Mu Tong, each one ounce; peeled black plums, and five-flavor fruit from the north, each half an ounce; mulberry mistletoe, licorice, and bitter stems, each half an ounce.

Grind these into a coarse powder. Each dose is three qian, boiled in one cup of water until reduced to six parts, taken warm.

Large Abdominal Peel Soup: For treating difficulty in urination and defecation during pregnancy or red stool.

Ingredients: Bitter orange peel, large abdominal peel, and red Poria, each one ounce; licorice two qian.

Grind these into a powder, and take two qian mixed with scallion white broth.

Danxi's Formula: For treating pregnancy at four months with constipation. Having used laxatives like winter sunflower seeds, though they have worked, the energy remains unbalanced due to impatience and blood depleting the energy. It’s necessary to harmonize the energy and nourish the blood for stability.

Ingredients: Dried orange peel, green orange peel, and peony root, each one qian; ginseng, Angelica sinensis, Chuanxiong, fresh Rehmannia, and white atractylodes, each half an ounce; Poria, Mu Tong, and licorice, each two fen.

Prepare with water.

Dusheng Powder: For treating difficulty in urination during pregnancy.

Ingredients: Vine flower seeds.

Duzheng Decoction: Treats abdominal pain in pregnant women.

Difu Dahuang Decoction (from "External Treatises"):
Treats urinary issues in pregnancy, suitable for purging.

Xu Duan Decoction: Treats bleeding during pregnancy and blood in the urine. Ingredients: Dang Gui, Sheng Di (each one liang), Xu Duan (half a liang), Chi Shao Yao (two and a half qian). Grind into a powder, take two qian on an empty stomach, mixed with a broth made from scallion whites.

Licorice, Wheat, and Jujube Decoction [from "Jin Gui"]: Treats dryness in women’s organs, feelings of sadness and desire to cry, as if affected by a spiritual being, and frequent yawning. Ingredients: Licorice (three liang), Wheat (one sheng), Jujube (ten pieces). Boil these three ingredients in six sheng of water until three sheng is left, and divide into three warm doses. It also tonifies spleen qi. One prescription says it can be used before and after childbirth.

Bamboo Shoot Decoction [from "Zhun Sheng"]: Treats heart deficiency with palpitations in pregnant women, continuous dryness, and sadness. Also very effective for severe anxiety. Ingredients: Mai Men Dong (with hearts removed), Wheat, and Ban Xia, each (two and a half liang), Ren Shen and Bai Fu Ling, each (one and a half liang), and Licorice (one liang). Grind these finely, take four qian each time, combined with five slices of ginger, one jujube, and a section of dried bamboo shoot the size of a finger, and decoct to drink warm.[165p]
Xiong Huang Bu Zhong Decoction [from "Ji Sheng Fang"]

This is used to treat weak blood and qi during pregnancy, unable to nourish and protect, leading to fetal instability, resulting in miscarriage every four to five months, termed "half birth."

Ingredients:

  • Xiong Huang (Sichuan Pepper)
  • Wu Wei Zi (Schisandra)
  • Ejiao (Donkey-hide Gelatin) and fried conch powder, each 1 qian (3 grams)
  • Gan Jiang (Dried Ginger), roasted
  • Huang Qi (Astragalus), roasted
  • Dang Gui (Angelica), soaked in wine
  • Bai Shao (White Peony), Bai Zhu (Atractylodes), each 1.5 qian
  • Du Zhong (Eucommia), stir-fried and stripped of fibers
  • Ren Shen (Ginseng), Mu Xiang (Costus), Gan Cao (Licorice), each 5 fen (1.5 grams)

Prepare with 2 sheng (600 ml) of water, simmer until 1 sheng remains, and consume at any time. If a formula lacks Mu Xiang, it still works.

Du Zhong Pill, also called "Du Xu Pill."

This treats instability of the fetus after two to three months of pregnancy, with back pain, preventing miscarriage; it is recommended to take it in advance.

Ingredients:

  • Du Zhong, processed with ginger and strip removed, 2 liang (approximately 60 grams)
  • Xu Duan (Teasel), soaked in wine, 2 liang

Grind into powder, boil jujube flesh, make pills the size of walnuts, take 70 pills with rice drink.

Four-Form Xiang Fu Pills

This treats women with repeated miscarriages due to improper qi movement, thus preventing strong fetal energy. It is advisable to take this.

Ingredients:

  • Xiang Fu (Cyperus), pounded and cleaned, 1 jin (approximately 600 grams), divided into four parts: one part soaked in wine, one part in vinegar, two parts in children's urine, one part in saltwater, each soaked for seven days, then dried.

Grind to a fine powder, boil with vinegar into a paste, and form pills the size of walnuts. Take 70 pills on an empty stomach with warm wine. If the person is overweight, follow the basic formula; if thin, add 2 liang each of Zexlan leaves and red Poria. Another formula uses 1 jin of Xiang Fu, 4 liang of Ai Ye (Mugwort), and 1 liang of Dang Gui, all boiled in vinegar.[166p]
Anxiety-relieving white atractylodes powder is used to treat pregnancy complications such as coldness, underdeveloped fetus, or loss of management, which can lead to miscarriage. This medicine nourishes the vital essence and supports the fetus's energy.

Ingredients:

  • Wuzhuyu soaked in soup (0.5 tael)
  • Honey-fried Licorice (1.5 taels)

Prepare a fine powder. Take 2 qian with warm wine before meals, avoiding raw and cold fruits.

Zhi Mu Pill: Treats pain resembling childbirth when the moon and sun have not yet fully risen, also helps with difficult childbirth and child-related troubles. Zhi Mu is not confined to a specific amount. Grind finely and form into pills the size of a chicken's head, chew with warm wine, take three times a day. A variant of the pill is the size of a walnut, take 20 pills with congee or 30 to 50 at a time.

Xiong Huang Pill: Treats pregnancies with ghost fetuses, resulting in abdominal pain and the discharge of dark blood. Finely grind Xiong Huang, hairless Gui Jiu, Mang Cao, Dan Sha, Bai Dou with skin and heart oil, half a tael each; one lizard and one centipede, both roasted until yellow. Grind finely and form into pills the size of a jujube, take two pills with warm wine on an empty stomach, twice a day, should provoke discharge. If not effective, increase to three pills. First, discharge clear water, then numerous worm-like creatures resembling horse tails may be expelled. For severe cases, snake-shaped worms, or things resembling frog eggs, chicken eggs, white paste, or bean juice may come out, after which the ailment will be resolved.

Fu Yuan Decoction: Treats constant vomiting in pregnancy, or headaches with complete loss of appetite, left pulse weak. Each: Dang Gui, Chuan Xiong, Bai Shao, Ren Shen, and Gan Cao (roasted), five qian each; Bai Zhu, Fu Ling, Chen Pi, one and a half tael each; three qian of Ding Xiang; Half Xie soaked in ginger soup, one tael; two qian of Jie Geng and Zhi Qiao. Prepare a total of ten doses, boiling with ginger and dates for consumption.[168p]
Zisu and Qi San: This remedy disperses Qi and regulates pregnancy, helping with any discomfort before delivery, such as distress, obstructed Qi, and various ailments before childbirth. The ingredients include Su Geng, Dong Quai, Chuan Xiong, White Peony, Ginseng, Dried Tangerine Peel, Licorice, and Large Gourd Skin. Grind them together, add one or two slices of fresh ginger and seven green onions, and boil in water for consumption. If there is abdominal pain, add Cyperus and Saussurea; if there is coughing, add Fructus Aurantii and Mulberry Bark; if there is severe heat, add Baikal Skullcap; if there is vomiting, add Cardamom; if there is diarrhea, add Atractylenolide and Poria; if there is difficulty in labor, add Fructus Aurantii, Cyperus, and Plantago seeds. If there is no Chuan Xiong, it is called Qibao Powder.

Bai Zhu San: This stabilizes pain and supports the fetus. Jihuang San: For treating children's dysentery with both red and white, accompanied by painful cramping. Ingredients: One black chicken egg, pouring out the clear fluid while retaining the yolk; Yellow Orpiment at one qian. Take one qian mixed with rice drink; if one dose cures, it indicates a boy; if two doses cure, it indicates a girl.[174p]
Duck broth is used to treat red and white dysentery before childbirth and after delivery. Use fresh ginger, costing 100 coins for the young and 200 coins for the old, and extract its juice. Take one duck, break it into the ginger juice and stir well. Cook until it’s 80% done, then add three coins of cattail pollen and simmer for another 5 to 7 boils. Consume warm on an empty stomach for immediate effect.

Hezi powder treats diarrhea during pregnancy caused by eating cold food or exposure to wind. Use 1.5 coins each of hezi peel and white atractylodes, and 1 coin each of dried tangerine peel, galanga, wood fragrance, fried white peony, cooked nutmeg, and roasted licorice. Crush these to make one dose, adding five slices of ginger, then boil with water to drink.

Xingpi drink is used to treat childhood malaria and cold malaria. Use 5 coins each of magnolia bark and cardamom, 3 fen of dried ginger, and 2 fen of licorice. Crush these to make one dose, adding five slices of ginger and two jujubes, then boil and consume on an empty stomach.

Jisheng gypsum soup is used to treat febrile malaria during pregnancy when there is excessive drinking. Use 2 coins of gypsum, 1 coin of raw rehmannia, and 1 coin each of pinellia, skullcap, ginseng, ophiopogon, anemarrhena, and dried kudzu; 5 fen of licorice. Crush these to make one dose, adding one black plum, then boil and consume.[175p]

Divine Formula for Fetal Examination
This formula is effective for confirming pregnancy.
True Sparrow Brain and Chuanxiong, 1 liang; Danggui, for those weighing 1 liang, only use 7 qian.

If you still don't feel it, boil with safflower and take down; it will surely be effective.

Good vinegar and moxa leaves.

Grind the above into powder; take 1 qian mixed with plain water as needed.

Fetal Source Drink: Treats women whose Chong and Ren meridians are unbalanced, resulting in an unstable pregnancy, modifying based on specific symptoms. Can be taken every other day or every two to three days for one or two doses.

Add 2 zhòng of water, decoct to 7 portions, and take warm far from meals.[180p]
Shou Pi Jian (Shou Pi Decoction), also known as She Ying Jian (Sheng Ying Decoction): Treats heart and spleen qi deficiency during pregnancy with restlessness of the fetus.

    Jie Gan Decoction: Used to treat stagnant liver qi during pregnancy, with symptoms of bloating and discomfort. Ingredients include half a qian of Chenpi (dried tangerine peel), Banxia (Pinellia tuber), Houpu (magnolia bark), and Fuling (Poria), seven fen of Sharen (cardamom), and one qian each of Suye (perilla leaf) and Shaoyao (peony root). Add one and a half sheng of water and three to five slices of fresh ginger, then decoct and take.

Hua Gan Decoction: Used to treat anger and liver qi combined with heat during pregnancy, causing fetal unease. Ingredients include two qian each of Qingpi (green tangerine peel), Chenpi, and Shaoyao, half a qian each of Zhi Zhi (fruits of Gardenia) and Danpi (Moutan root), two to three qian of Tu Beimu (bulb of Fritillaria), and one and a half sheng of water. Decoct to seven or eight parts, and take warm after meals. If there is blood seen in the lower part, substitute licorice for Ze Xie (Alisma).

Zi Su Drink: Used to treat pregnancy imbalance, fetal unease, and upper abdominal pain, referred to as "the child hanging." It may also address issues of energy stagnation near labor. Ingredients include half a liang each of Ren Shen (ginseng) and Gan Cao (licorice), and one liang each of Dabu Pi (large abdomen peel), Chuan Xiong (Sichuan lovage), Bai Shao (white peony), Chen Pi, Su Ye, and Dang Gui (Angelica). Each serving consists of one liang, decocted in ginger and scallion water. There is a variation with Xiangfu (Cyperus) instead of ginseng, and another without Chuan Xiong, known as Qibao Powder. If there is liver and spleen qi and blood deficiency with heat and unease, combine with Xiao Yao Powder. If there is spleen qi deficiency and unease, use Si Jun Qiung Gui Decoction.

Wu Wei Yi Gong Powder: Used to treat spleen and stomach qi deficiency with nausea during pregnancy. Ingredients include one qian each of Ren Shen, Bai Zhu (Atractylodes), Fuling, Zhi Gan Cao, and Chenpi, with ginger and jujube added, decocted and taken.[183p]
Liuwèi Yìgōng San: Treats gastrointestinal deficiency during pregnancy, especially with excessive vomiting due to cold. Ingredients: 2-3 qian of ginseng, 2 qian each of white atractylodes and poria, 1 qian each of dried tangerine peel and roasted licorice, and 1-2 qian of stir-fried dried ginger. Boil with 1.5 zhōng of water and take as a decoction.

Héwèi Yǐn: Treats cold and excess qi in the stomach during pregnancy, with the fetus exerting pressure upwards. Ingredients: 1.5 qian each of dried tangerine peel, magnolia bark, and ginger, 1-2 qian of stir-fried dried ginger, and 1 qian of roasted licorice. Boil with 0.5 zhōng of water, reduce to seven parts, and take warm.

Wǔ Jūnzǐ Jiān: Treats spleen deficiency with cold during pregnancy, also with the fetus exerting pressure upwards. Ingredients: ginseng as needed, 2 qian each of white atractylodes and poria, 1 qian of roasted licorice, and 1-2 qian of stir-fried ginger. Boil with 1.5 zhōng of water and take as a decoction.

Qīng Huà Yǐn: Treats postpartum heat due to fire, as well as chaotic blood heat, yin deficiency, and other symptoms related to unclear fire. Also treats blood heat and leakage during pregnancy. Ingredients: 2 qian each of peony and ophiopogon, 2-3 qian each of moutan root, poria, and scutellaria, and 1 qian of dendrobium. Boil with 1.5 zhōng of water, reduce to seven parts, and take warm away from meals.

Sì Shèng Sǎn: Treats bleeding during miscarriage. Ingredients: equal parts of scutellaria, white atractylodes, sand ginger, and gelatin. Grind to a fine powder; take 2 qian each time, mixed with moxibustion broth. One variation includes peony and omits gelatin. If made into a decoction, reduce the amount of sand ginger by half.[184p]
