Chi Jin Dou: Also known as Ba Xian Dan. Used to treat ghost pregnancy.
Ingredients:

  • 1.5 qian of Ba Shuang (removed from the skin, slightly defatted)
  • 2 qian of Fried Soap Pod (Zao Jiao) until slightly charred
  • 2 qian each of Raw Aconite (Sheng Fu Zi, cut and slightly roasted) and Cinnabar (Zhu Sha)
  • 1 qian of Light Powder (Qing Fen)
  • 3 qian each of Clove (Ding Xiang), Aromatic Wood (Mu Xiang), and Yellow Turmeric (Tian Zhu Huang)
  • Grind the above into a fine powder, soak in vinegar and steam into pills the size of radish seeds, coated with Cinnabar. For gradual effect, take 5 to 7 pills each time; for immediate effect, take 10 to 20 pills. Use boiling water, or decoct with ginger, vinegar, tea, honey, anise, or herbal decoction as a guide for ingestion. If it flows excessively, drink a couple of sips of cold water to stop. This medicine acts in heat and stops in cold.

Single Formula:
To calm the fetus and regulate Qi: Grind fried Cyperus (Xiang Fu Zi) into powder and decoct a strong infusion of Perilla (Zi Su), taking 1 to 2 qian. May also add Sha Ren (Amomum). 【Hua Tuo】[186p]
Movements of the fetus during pregnancy: One penny of powdered vermilion, mixed with the whites of three eggs, stir evenly and take at once; if the fetus is dead, it will be expelled; if not, it will be settled.

For fetal distress, gas not rising or falling, and vomiting blood and sour liquid: One penny each of cyperus, patchouli, and licorice, powdered; take two pennies each time, add a little salt, and take with boiling water.

For unstable fetal movements, back pain, fetal turning causing heart distress, continuous bleeding, or premature labor: Use one to two liters of juice from the root of sweet flag.

For abdominal pain during pregnancy, back pain, heart distress, continuous bleeding, or a dead fetus in the womb: One size of mugwort leaves, four liters of wine; boil down to two liters, and take in two doses.

For painful fetal movements pressing against the heart: One size of mugwort leaves, four liters of vinegar; boil down to two liters, and take warm in divided doses.

For pregnancy-related illnesses where the fetus cannot settle: Take four taels of special yeast from the seventh day of the seventh month, two large cups of water, boil down to one cup and three parts, strain out the residue, and take warm in three doses to induce expulsion.

Another formula: Use five liters of major yeast and one斗 of clear wine, boil and skim, divide into five doses, avoid eating until the next evening, but upon taking again, it will be expelled like porridge, with no suffering for the mother.

For fetal pain wanting to be delivered when the due date has not yet arrived: Use one whole snake skin, place it in a silk bag and tie it around the waist.[187p]
When fetal movements are restless, accompanied by back pain or discomfort in the chest, or if there is bleeding: Use twenty stalks of white scallion, boil them in strong juice and drink. If the fetus is not dead, it will stabilize; if it is dead, it will be expelled—an effective remedy.

For excessive fetal movement during pregnancy: Warmly take the juice from fermented soybeans; this is from the Hua Tuo recipe. Another method: Grind fresh wheat cakes into powder, mix with water to extract juice, and take three sheng warm.

If the fetus is about to fall with unbearable abdominal pain: Use two liang of ramie root, cut finely, and decoct with equal parts of wine and water. Another method: Take one dried lotus stalk, roast and grind it, mix with a bowl of glutinous rice wash, and take it to settle the condition.

For abdominal pain in a pregnant woman: Burn car oil powder and mix it into wine to drink at will.

If fetal movement causes abdominal pain or leads to yellow fluid discharge resembling lacquer or bean juice: Use five qian each of wild ramie root and honeysuckle root, decoct with equal parts of water and wine. Another method: Use two qian of processed deer antler glue powdered into beads, and mix with rice drink.

Another method: Use good silver to boil and take the water, adding scallion oil for consumption is good. Another method: Use ramie root, one foot long, about the size of a finger, chew it, and boil in five liters of water to yield three liters, then remove the residue to drink. Adding five slices of fresh ginger is also acceptable. Danxi stated that ramie root can greatly nourish Yin and promote blood circulation.[188p]
During pregnancy, if there is fetal movement accompanied by persistent crying, mouth and lips twitching, and relentless severe diarrhea: use five taels of mugwort leaves, boil them together with five sheng of good wine, take four sheng, strain, and further decoct to obtain one sheng. For those unable to open their mouths, administer orally, and healing will occur immediately.

If there is unexplained bleeding during pregnancy that does not stop: take three taels of donkey-hide gelatin, roast and crush into powder, mix with one and a half sheng of wine, decoct until dissolved, and one dose will heal. Another method: take two taels of donkey-hide gelatin powdered, half a jin of fresh rehmannia to extract juice, and mix with three sheng of clear wine, strain the juice, and divide into three doses.

For fetal movement accompanied by a sensation of impending miscarriage: take one qian of fried cardamom seeds powdered, and administer with wine or salt water.

For persistent bleeding associated with a threatened miscarriage: use ashes from dried peach fruit that has not fallen from the tree, mix with water and ingest for healing. The "Bencao" states that peach kernels break blood and also treat accumulations from stagnated qi.

For heart pain during pregnancy: use one sheng of young bamboo shoots, two sheng of wine, boil to obtain one sheng, strain, and take warm in divided doses. Another method: use one broken chicken egg mixed with wine and take.

For fetal movement threatening to miscarry, with unbearable abdominal pain: use one jin of high-quality silver, two taels of sedge roots (discarding the black skin), boil in nine sheng of water to obtain five sheng of silver solution, add one sheng of clear wine, continue to decoct with sedge roots, take three sheng, divided into three doses, and stability will be achieved immediately.[189p]

  • For back pain during pregnancy that recurs: Take deer antler about six inches long, burn it until red, then quench it in wine, burn again and quench again. Crush the antler to measure, and drink the wine in which it has been quenched.

  • For women who are weak and have ghost fetus symptoms with menstrual irregularities: Take three taels of ground Euphorbia root, fry until yellow, reducing to powder; take one qian per dose mixed with a decoction of peach kernels to eliminate toxins and promote recovery.
  • For breast abscess during pregnancy: Use five qian of soft white aromatic spice from Hongzhou, a cup of water, and a piece of beef gelatin; cook until the mixture is seven-tenths warm, then drink. Another method: Drink the boiled juice of Job's tears.
  • If the child cries in the abdomen: Brew a strong decoction of Coptis and the mother should sip this regularly.[196p]
    Due to bleeding caused by shock during pregnancy: take powdered Huanglian mixed with wine and consume a small spoonful, three times a day.

For pregnant women with trouble sleeping due to dryness and restlessness: take one qian of powdered Huanglian with congee. Alternatively, wine-steamed Huanglian pills are also effective.

For severe illness leading to miscarriage: ten pieces of a certain worm, roasted and ground into powder, taken with wine will cause the fetus to expel.

To nourish fetal energy: when the fetus reaches nine months, consume one pig's stomach, cooked with the usual five flavors until finished.

To change a female fetus to male: take one string from a bow or crossbow and place it in a red pouch worn on the left arm of the woman. Another method: take one liang of realgar and place it in a red pouch worn on the arm. For desiring a girl, wear calamine. Another method: place an axe under the bed of the woman in labor, with the blade facing down, ensuring no one is aware. Yet another method for a woman who has just realized she is pregnant: take one qian of silkworm feces and consume it with well water, three times a day.

As for acupuncture:

"The Essentials of the Golden Coffer" states: if a woman suffers a miscarriage, feeling fullness in the abdomen and not able to urinate, with heaviness below the waist resembling water retention for seven months, the Taiyin needs to be nourished; this means the heart energy is full, and one should needle the Laogong and Guanyuan points. If urination improves, she will recover.

"The Classic of Acupuncture" states: if the child discharges red or white discharge, needle the Yaoyang point. For women's post-lactation ailments, needle the Chongmen point.[197p]
The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: In the third month of pregnancy, if the fetus is at risk of miscarriage, moxibustion should be applied one inch below the knee at seven spots. In the first month of pregnancy, nourish the foot jueyin pulse; in the second month, nourish the foot shaoyang pulse; in the third month, nourish the hand xin main pulse; in the fourth month, nourish the hand shaoyang pulse; in the fifth month, nourish the foot taiyin pulse; in the sixth month, nourish the foot yangming pulse; in the seventh month, nourish the hand taiyin pulse; in the eighth month, nourish the hand yangming pulse; in the ninth month, nourish the foot shaoyin pulse. Each month, when nourishing the fetus with these pulses, acupuncture or moxibustion should not be performed.

The "Medical Introduction" states: Pregnant women should not undergo acupuncture at Hegu (LI4) or Sanyinjiao (SP6).

When a woman is about to give birth, if the fetus has already ruptured, and foul water flows continuously, and there is early cessation of blood to nourish, leading to exhaustion, puncture the point at Duyin (the fifth point of the Yinqiao) between the third joint of the little toe, five-tenths of an inch into Chengyin.

The "Danxi Heart Method" states: If there are alternating chills and fever, coughing with blood and phlegm, or vomiting with loss of appetite and weakness, or chest fullness with pain along the spine, or a mouth that produces saliva like frost and snow, without speech, or tinnitus, or excessive phlegm and saliva day and night, it is due to the misuse of hot medicines. Puncture Fengmen (BL12) and Po Hu (BL42) each by five-tenths of an inch, and through the point at Zhigou (TE5). If chills and fever persist, puncture the absolute bones (Yao) at five-tenths of an inch, and Taixi (KD3) at three-tenths of an inch. If the pulse and qi are still unbalanced, then drain Taiyuan (LU9) and Taibai (SP3) each by two-tenths of an inch. Heat accumulation at unspecified points can be treated by draining for immediate effect or nourishing for deficient conditions to resolve pre-labor issues. After the condition stabilizes, there will surely be a change within half a year; if limbs become emaciated and the abdomen swells, then puncture Yinjiao (SP6) to remove the harmful substances.[198p]
Medical Case

The text from "The Filial Conduct of the Confucian School" states: A person from Dai went to Dong Qi, where a woman was suffering from severe constipation and difficult urination, having been unable to conceive for half her life. When she took a laxative, her bowels moved freely, but when she stopped the medicine, her condition would worsen. Suddenly, she became pregnant, and during the fourth or fifth month, the physician prohibited laxatives, leading to her usual difficulty with bowel movements. When she tried to defecate, she exerted herself greatly, resulting in a miscarriage. This happened three times. By the time she became pregnant for the third or fourth month, both her urine and bowel movements were still difficult, and she felt a sweet separation from her pregnancy, prompting her to consult the person from Dai. Upon examining her pulse, the physician found it slippery and strong, but because she was pregnant, he didn’t dare to apply strong treatments and opted for dietary therapy instead. He prepared dishes using flower alkali to cook water chestnuts and sunflower greens, made porridge with plantago seeds mixed with pig and sheep blood for her to eat. After half a year, she miraculously gave birth, and her constipation was finally cured.[199p]
Mr. Liu's wife was six months pregnant but experienced bleeding due to an injury, so she sought medicine from Mr. Dai. Mr. Dai diagnosed her and prescribed a combination of Sanhe Decoction, Yuzhu Powder, Chengqi Decoction, and Siwu Decoction, adding a decoction of (Shibu) Nitrate. After several doses, the pain, which felt as if pinched by hand, ceased and the bleeding also stopped.

A woman over forty became pregnant, believing that due to her age and many ailments, her sickness had returned and reported this to the physician. The physician, failing to investigate properly, applied moxibustion around her navel and used toxic medicine to attack her condition, resulting in increased abdominal pain, reduced appetite, and she grew gaunt, eventually lying in bed. She sought Mr. Dai's help. Mr. Dai checked her pulse and said: "All six pulses are even, but the pulse at the right wrist is strong and large; this indicates pregnancy." Everyone laughed at him. A few months later, she gave birth to a girl, whose lower eyelids bore marks from moxibustion, nearly losing her sight. It is crucial to inquire about pregnancy first when treating women; one must not act hastily.

The wife of King Hu was afflicted with a mass below her navel, along with vomiting and loss of appetite; she appeared pale and emaciated with no menstrual flow. Some suggested it was due to a lack of blood and qi, but treatment was ineffective. Mr. Dai observed her and declared she was pregnant, though the person did not believe it. After repeated requests for treatment from Mr. Dai, he gave her a mild remedy to satisfy her desire but refused to prescribe toxic medicine. Eventually, after a month, she indeed gave birth. When asked how he recognized it, Mr. Dai replied: "The pulse at the wrist is strong and large; as mentioned in the 'Suwen,' it refers to the distinction between yin and yang as indicated by the pulse."[200p]
Zhu Zhenheng's "Mind Method" states: A woman, three months pregnant, experiences phlegm and water along with food every day, feeling a rushing sensation in the lower abdomen during the early morning. At these times, she feels fullness in the diaphragm, followed by vomiting, a flushed face with slight agitation, dizziness, inability to rise from bed, and aching limbs with mild thirst. This indicates liver fire along with the Qi of the Chong vessel rushing upwards. Some days are worse, some are better. The pulse is harmonious, yet the right inch pulse is strong and large. If a hundred medications are ineffective, one should wait two months. Occasionally, using sandalwood to grind in water to dissolve the Bao Long Wan, one dose can relieve the fullness in the diaphragm and prevent the Qi from rushing upwards; after two or three doses, vomiting stops, dizziness reduces, and eating becomes stable.

A woman from the Ying family, seven months pregnant, sometimes vomits food, with the fetus causing fullness and obstruction beneath the heart, Qi attacking the back, and both elbows pained, needing someone to constantly rub and press. By applying heat and massaging, she manages to vomit a little, with a strong pulse. The remedy consisted of two and a half qian of huang qin, one qian of stir-fried huang lian, two qian each of stir-fried bai zhu and ban xia, five fen each of roasted gan cao and sha ren, one qian each of chen pi, dang gui, shan zhi, stir-fried zhi ke, xiang fu, ren shen, and cang zhu, and one and a half qian of fu ling, along with seven slices of fresh ginger. After taking two doses, the chaotic vomiting ceased and the fullness diminished. However, during the night, she experienced back and elbow pain, so she applied heat again, and subsequently took the Bao Long Wan, which relieved the ailment as if it were gone.[201p]
A woman nearing thirty years of age, two months pregnant, suffered from vomiting and dizziness, feeling that she could not withstand it. She took ginseng, astragalus, chuanxiong, dried tangerine peel, and poria, but after five or seven days, felt increasingly heavy. I was called to pulse diagnose her; both hands showed a string-like pulse, particularly weak on the left side. I said: "This is a case of adverse pregnancy conditions, certainly agitated by anger." Upon inquiry, this proved true. With the liver's qi counterflowing and intertwined with the fetal qi, tonics like ginseng and astragalus were highly inappropriate. I advised her to take a decoction of poria and to use 24 pills of Yiqing Wan, after which she felt somewhat better. Upon examining her pulse, there were slight irregularities; she reported dry mouth and bitterness, and that eating congee made her mouth sour. I suspected this was due to stagnant qi in the diaphragm. I instructed her to take a herbal formulation of chuanxiong, dried tangerine peel, gardenia fruit, poria, and ginger, plus 15 pills of Yiqing Wan. After ten days, her remaining symptoms were resolved, but she noticed a sour taste after meals and felt easily hungry when not eating. I said the liver heat had not yet subsided. I instructed her to take a light broth with 20 pills of Yiqing Wan, and after twenty days, she was stable. Upon checking her pulse again, although both hands showed peace, the pulse on the right was still weak; thus, I warned that a miscarriage was imminent. Now that the liver's qi was balanced, ginseng and astragalus could be used. I began using these tonics to prevent miscarriage, addressing her future deficiency. After one month of this treatment, she miscarried but remained calm and without issues afterward. Yiqing Wan consists solely of a single ingredient, huanglian (coptis).[202p]
A woman who was six months pregnant suddenly had convulsions, with her limbs stiffening and her face turning dark purple. She closed her eyes and drooled, becoming delirious and unresponsive for a while before waking up. The doctor applied over fifty doses of an invigorating pill, but her condition came and went without any improvement. It was only when she was about to give birth that she recovered. She delivered a girl, and both mother and child were safe.

The following year, her husband suspected that she might suffer from the same troubling condition again, so he sought treatment. When her pulse was checked, it was floating and string-like; upon deeper examination, it was solid and submerged at the bone. Since it was mid-February and her previous convulsions had occurred in May, he was cautious about administering medicine, intending to wait until the appropriate time when he anticipated the condition would recur. By mid-May, her symptoms did indeed return, both in the year of the snake and the horse. He then instructed her to prepare a self-made formula of Feng Tong Sheng powder, using raw licorice with more peach kernels and a little safflower. Whether taking it or expelling it, after four to five doses, her condition gradually became milder, and she ultimately recovered from a rash.[203p]
A woman in her thirties, pregnant for four months, was suffering from constipation and had difficulty urinating. After taking some medicines including winter melon seeds, she was able to relieve herself, but her energy remained unbalanced. This was caused by her impatience, which had depleted her blood and disrupted her energy. Therefore, I prescribed soothing medications to nourish her energy and blood, bringing her comfort.

Another woman, aged forty-one, was nine months pregnant and had not urinated for three days. She was in severe pain, with swollen legs and felt she could not survive. When I examined her, I found her condition weakened, with a rapid pulse on the right and a slightly more stable pulse on the left. This condition arose from food stagnation harming her energy, making her fetus unable to lift itself and pressing against the bladder, causing her inability to urinate. This is generally how the condition of troubled pregnancy manifests.

I then prepared a prescription to nourish her blood and energy. Once her blood and energy were rectified, the fetus would lift itself, preventing further descent, which would bring her peace of mind. Therefore, I used ginseng, angelica root, white peony, white atractylodes, dried tangerine peel, roasted licorice, pinellia, and ginger, decocting them into a strong soup. I gave her four doses, allowing her to drink frequently. By the next morning, I also prepared the residue from the four doses into one more decoction, instructing her to drink it quickly and to induce vomiting to release the medicinal soup. This led to immediate urination, which was dark.

Subsequently, I augmented this prescription with large belly peel, bitter orange, green scallion leaves, and twenty doses of cardamom, to prevent weakness before and after delivery. Ultimately, she achieved a safe delivery and remained healthy post childbirth.[204p]
A woman who was seven or eight months pregnant suffered from urinary obstruction, and despite the efforts of numerous doctors, she could not find relief. Her condition worsened with increasing urgency and swelling, and upon examining her pulse, it was weak and thin. I suspected that her blood and energy were insufficient to support the fetus, causing it to descend and press against the bladder opening, making it impossible for her to urinate. I recommended that she take tonifying medicine to uplift and support the fetus, which would then relieve the obstruction. Before the medicine could take effect, the urgency increased further. Thus, I instructed an elderly woman to use fragrant oil on her hands, enter through the delivery door, and support the fetus. As a result, she was able to urinate profusely, and the swelling and urgency immediately alleviated. At the same time, I prescribed a large dose of ginseng, astragalus, and licorice to be decocted and taken. If there was still some urgency, she would continue to support the fetus to aid urination. After three days of this treatment, the fetus gradually rose, and her urination returned to normal.[205p]
A woman became pregnant but was likely to miscarry by the third month. I instructed her to prepare a strong decoction of white atractylodes and, mixed with two qian of huangqin powder, to take it for three to four weeks, which allowed her to carry the pregnancy to term. This is because pregnancy, reaching the third month, is associated with yang fire, making miscarriage more likely. Otherwise, how could huangqin and white atractylodes be known as wonderful medicines to secure a pregnancy?

A woman over thirty, who had either experienced missed periods or an incomplete physical form in her pregnancy, faced inevitable miscarriage. Observing her temperament—impatient, easily angered, with a dark complexion and strong energy—showed that her yang fire was too excessive; thus, she could not sustain the vital energy to nourish the fetus, and instead, her appetite harmed her vital essence. Therefore, I instructed her to stop menstruation in the second month and used huangqin, white atractylodes, angelica, and licorice, advising her to continue until the end of the third month, which led to the birth of a son.

The "Miscellaneous Writings of Ming Medicine" states: My wife once had a miscarriage, and one day experienced heavy bleeding, which resulted in contractions. I gave her a remedy using the urine of a child to awaken her and soon returned the contractions. I urgently prepared a decoction of schizonepeta, administering it as her contractions recurred. However, the medicines to stop the bleeding were ineffective, and suddenly she vomited. I provided her with the child’s urine and found it filled her chest. I used my hand to induce vomiting, and after a short while, she expelled a bowl of rice and pickled vegetables. When inquiring about this incident, she had become angry just after lunch, which caused the bleeding to continue. I concluded that due to her recent fullness of food, her stomach energy was stagnant, leading to severe bleeding. Since the bleeding was substantial, her stomach energy was further depleted, resulting in the ineffectiveness of the medicine. Therefore, I urgently needed to regulate her spleen and stomach, and thus I used five qian of white atractylodes, along with two qian each of dried tangerine peel and barley sprouts, which she took as a decoction. Before long, her contractions stopped, and after an additional dose, the bleeding ceased.[206p]
Thus, one must focus on treating the spleen and stomach, taking several doses, allowing the stomach energy to gradually return, and then adding blood tonics to ensure recovery. If one does not carefully evaluate the presence of food stagnation and then administers blood-stopping or blood-moving medicines, would that not be a mistake? Generally, physicians treating various diseases must constantly observe if there is injury from food accumulation. If the patient experiences fullness and discomfort in the chest, vomiting, belching, sour throat, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or aversion to food, one should ask about their recent diet. Upon confirming injury from food stagnation, adjustments to the spleen and stomach should be made first to digest and regulate the food, and then the primary disease can be treated, or digestive aids can be added to the main medicinal formula. Failing to recognize this may result in using appropriate medicines without effect. The spleen and stomach are fundamentally important; if the stomach energy is damaged, it cannot process the medicinal flavors to achieve results. Additionally, there are cases where one takes medicine right after eating, or sleeps immediately after taking medicine, or takes excessive amounts of medicine, which is termed harming the medicine. It is essential to be aware of these situations.[207p]
The "Medical Cases of Xue Ji" states:

A pregnant woman experience vomiting and aversion to food, feeling fatigued and wanting to sleep; this is due to a deficiency of stomach qi and obstruction. Two doses of ginseng and tangerine peel decoction gradually improved her condition, followed by one dose of Six Gentlemen's Decoction with perilla leaf for stabilization.

A pregnant woman feels sourness and nausea, sometimes wanting to vomit; this is because of a deficiency in spleen and stomach, leading to food stagnation. She was treated with Six Gentlemen's Decoction combined with bitter orange and nutmeg, resulting in recovery.

A pregnant woman experiences vomiting, with abdominal distension and alternating chills and fever, her complexion is pale yellow; this indicates excess of wood affecting the spleen and earth. She was treated with Six Gentlemen's Decoction added with bupleurum, balloon flower, and bitter orange for stabilization.

A pregnant woman vomits sour fluid and feels fullness in her chest, not wanting to eat; this is due to deficiency in spleen earth, being bullied by liver wood. Her condition improved with Six Gentlemen's Decoction plus peony, and she was further treated with Four Gentlemen's Decoction with bitter orange and balloon flower for stabilization.

A pregnant woman has abdominal and chest distension, vomits phlegm and has no appetite; this indicates deficiency in spleen and stomach with phlegm caused by food. She gradually improved with pinellia and poria decoction, and was later treated with Six Gentlemen's Decoction plus bitter orange, perilla stem, and balloon flower, allowing her to eat normally. Later, due to anger, she experienced flank distension, loss of appetite, vomiting phlegm and nausea; she was treated with pinellia and poria decoction combined with bupleurum and gardenia, which led to her recovery.[208p]
A pregnant woman experiences internal heat and fever in the afternoon, possibly accompanied by chills and fever, with diminished appetite and thoughts. A pregnant woman has blood discharge, experiences fever and thirst, and feels fatigued with reduced appetite. This is due to a deficiency of spleen qi being insulted by liver fire. Use Four Gentlemen Decoction with Chaihu and Shan Zhi Zhi for blood cessation. If anger arises again and the bleeding restarts, switch to Six Gentlemen Decoction with Chaihu, Shan Zhi Zhi, and Shengma for stability.

In the third month of pregnancy, her menstrual period may come three to five times, though not heavily. She maintains her appetite and spirits; this indicates excess blood. When the child grows large enough to drink, it will no longer come. Indeed, this is correct.[209p]
During a six-month pregnancy, a woman experienced frequent anger and bleeding, along with chills, fever, headaches, distension in the sides, abdominal pain, nausea, and reduced appetite. I concluded that the chills and headaches were due to liver fire rising, the distension and pain were caused by obstructed liver qi, the nausea and reduced appetite were due to the liver insulting the spleen and stomach, and the blood in the urine indicated heat in the liver and blood. A pregnant woman felt pressure in her abdomen, had fullness in her chest, burped frequently, and ate little. This indicated stagnation of spleen qi. I administered Zi Su drink for immediate relief, and later combined Si Jun Zi Tang with Zhi Ke, Chai Hu, and Shan Zhi, and she recovered.

One more pregnant woman, after becoming angry, experienced ineffective digestion and a reduced appetite. A pregnant woman, due to anger, experienced alternating chills and fever, internal heat and afternoon heat, pain in the flanks and vomiting. When the fetus reached eight months, it did not grow. A pregnant woman, due to anger, vomits blood clots and does not stop for four days. There is bloating and pain in the sides, with difficult urination. A pregnant woman, six months along, felt fatigued and lacked appetite, her face was pale and hot in the afternoon, yet the fetus was not growing and there was a risk of miscarriage due to overwork. This indicated a deficiency in the spleen’s energy. Another pregnant woman was unable to extend her limbs; after taking a remedy to expel wind and dry dampness, she had severe stool and phlegm retention. A woman who had toiled hard had irregular menstruation with alternating chills and fever. A pregnant woman had a sudden onset of diarrhea, which had since stopped, but she did not want to eat or drink. She experienced a sour taste in her mouth and frequent urges to relieve herself. Minister Bian's concubine experienced diarrhea during her pregnancy. In the case of the scholar Wang, he experienced diarrhea and a dislike of food during his pregnancy, accompanied by nausea. I said: This is due to damage to the spleen's qi. In the case of the official Hu Chengfu, who suffered from long-term pregnancy-related diarrhea and used medicines to alleviate Qi stagnation, her abdomen felt heavy and the fetal energy was unstable. I noted that the heaviness in her abdomen indicated a deficiency of vital energy, and the fetal movement unrest pointed to excessive internal heat. I prescribed the Ba Zhen Decoction for nourishment and stability, and then the Liu Junzi Decoction, which led to her recovery.

In the case of the official Wang Tiancheng, who experienced diarrhea during pregnancy and was constipated later, his family, being of medical background, tried cooling remedies without effect. Upon examining his pulse, I found it floating and large but weak, indicating a deficiency of Qi and blood. In the morning, I recommended Ba Zhen Decoction with added peach kernel and apricot kernel, and in the evening, I prescribed a modified version of the Xiaoyao Powder with plantago seeds, which resulted in his recovery.

For the student Li Xinggang, whose wife was five months pregnant and had difficulty urinating, none of the various medicines worked. I remarked that only the Ba Wei Pill could save her. Disbelieving, she used a different diuretic, which caused her abdomen to swell, making it difficult for her to get up.

In the case of the scholar Wang Wenyuan's wife, who was pregnant and had difficulty urinating and significant abdominal swelling, she was nearly in a critical condition. After taking the Ba Wei Jiu Yi dose, her urination became dribbling; upon adding plantago seeds to the pill, her abdomen's swelling rapidly diminished and she stabilized.

There was a woman who would experience anger leading to heat, side swelling, and dribbling urination, resembling her menstrual period; this lasted for over ten days. At three months pregnant, due to anger, her previous symptoms recurred. In the morning, I prescribed a modified version of the Xiaoyao Powder, and in the evening, an An Tai Decoction, both two doses each, which brought her peace. In the fifth month, after another bout of anger, she bled as if menstruating, which lasted four days without stopping. I repeated the previous medicines, leading to her recovery.[215p]
A pregnant woman experienced retention of urine and internal heat, with her liver pulse being strong and rapid. Upon examination, there were slight tension in the pulse, and she sometimes felt pain in both temples, along with fullness in the flanks. I believed it was due to liver fire and blood deficiency, so I prescribed a modified Xiao Yao San and Liu Wei Di Huang Wan, and she gradually recovered. Later, she had alternating chills and fever, or feelings of heat, or irritability, with previous symptoms recurring. I used Ba Zhen San and Xiao Yao San together to clear liver fire and nourish liver blood, leading to her recovery.

Another pregnant woman suffered from blood in her urine due to anger, experienced thirst from internal heat, and had alternating chills and fevers. She felt fullness in her chest and breasts, had little appetite, and her liver pulse was weak and stringy, indicating liver channel blood deficiency with heat. I prescribed a modified Xiao Yao San and Liu Wei Di Huang Wan together, and she gradually improved. I then used Ba Zhen Tang with Chai Hu, Dan Pi, and Shan Zhi, leading to her recovery.

One pregnant woman, by the fifth month of each pregnancy, felt bodily fatigue, had tasteless food, and experienced swelling in her legs that gradually extended to her entire body, eventually affecting her head and face. This was due to spleen and lung qi deficiency. I prescribed Bu Zhong Yi Qi in the morning and Liu Jun Zi with Su Geng in the evening, leading to her recovery. In treating pregnancy, do not get bogged down by the number of months; simply observe the symptoms of a specific channel and use appropriate remedies.

Another pregnant woman stopped eating and took Zhi Zhu Wan, but continued to experience discomfort in her chest and abdomen, with increasing loss of appetite. I prescribed digestive and relaxing medications, but her fetus was lower than normal. I assessed this as spleen qi deficiency that could not support the pregnancy. I used Bu Zhong Yi Qi and Liu Jun Zi Tang, gradually strengthening the central qi, which helped stabilize her fetus. I also used Ba Zhen Tang with Chai Hu and Sheng Ma for regulation, leading to her full recovery.[216p]
A pregnant woman, feeling sorrow without reason, recovered after taking two doses of jujube soup. Later, she experienced the same issue again and took the previous soup supplemented with four gentlemen's decoction and added gardenia, which brought her peace.

A pregnant woman was distressed and restless. When her husband asked her, she said she felt sad for no reason. She was given a gentle bamboo shoot soup as the main remedy, supplemented with an eight treasures soup, which helped her feel calm.

A pregnant woman had a fever and thirst, and her body ached all over. She took two doses of the Immortal Vitality Decoction, which slightly alleviated her symptoms. On the 11th day, over a hundred pox appeared on her body, and she felt extremely fatigued. A remedy of lithospermum and aromatic wood was used, and some relief was obtained. However, she still felt dry and thirsty, so she was given ginseng and white atractylodes powder to quench her thirst, followed by an eight treasures soup with added bupleurum and moutan, which helped expel pus. Later, they removed moutan and bupleurum and increased the ginseng and astragalus, administering several doses until the pox marks improved.

A woman at eight months of pregnancy felt her fetus descending or moving, her face was pale, and she felt fatigued with little appetite; she was diagnosed with weak spleen energy. She took a tonifying central qi decoction with increased white atractylodes and added siler; after over thirty doses, she felt better. After childbirth, she had dizziness, fullness in her chest, and a cough. She was treated with a four substances decoction supplemented with poria, pinellia, and balloon flower until she recovered.

According to the "Principles and Guidelines of Diagnosis and Treatment," it is noted that the wife of a general during her pregnancy suffered from persistent dysentery. When the immortal physician examined her pulse, it was found to be weak and slippery, and her two pulses were very thin. This was due to disharmony in the fetal qi, with excess fire causing heat, resembling dysentery but not being it. Therefore, yellow qin and white atractylodes were used to stabilize the fetus, along with four substances and raw rehmannia to regulate the blood, and after several doses, she was stabilized.[217p]
The divine physician of Bole, known as Hao Weng, was consulted by a scholar named Chen Yaozun regarding his wife's illness, which many doctors believed to be due to overexertion. Hao said: "Quickly stop the medicine; this is a symptom of pregnancy, and congratulations to you on expecting a son." Eventually, this was indeed the case.

Another two women were pregnant: one was mute and could not speak. Hao indicated: "The fetus is obstructing the channels; once the child is born, she will speak again. Do not poison her with medicine." The other woman was robust and strong; Hao diagnosed her pulse and said: "The mother’s energy has already diminished, hence the child survives by relying on the child’s energy." As expected, the child was born, but the mother died.

A woman was violently thirsty, drinking only a five-flavor juice. The renowned physician Geng Yu diagnosed her pulse and said: "This is blood wanting to coagulate, not an illness." Eventually, she became pregnant. There is an ancient formula that recognizes the symptom of thirst and coagulation of blood, which should not be overlooked.

Doctor Pan Jing diagnosed that the wife of Yu's Assistant Officer Zhang Xian had been pregnant for five years, the wife of Nanling's Wei Fu Changling for two years, and the concubine of the envoy Liu Yi Sun for fourteen months, none of whom had given birth. Old man Pan looked at them and declared: "This is a sickness; all doctors mistakenly consider this pregnancy." Consequently, he administered potent medicines to break the blood and expel toxins. The wife of the Assistant Officer expelled over a hundred flesh-like clots; Wei Changling's wife dreamed of two dark-skinned boys who abruptly fled in fear; Yi Sun's concubine gave birth to a large snake, which was still squirming and not yet dead. All three women were unscathed.

Ye Nanzhou's wife had not menstruated for five months and had discharges of white or red, along with afternoon fevers, coughing, and vomiting. Doctors diagnosed her with consumption from overexertion. Chen Douyan examined her and said: "Both pulses are firm; she must be pregnant, affected by external wind evils." He prescribed a gentle harmonizing remedy and she gave birth to two sons six months later.[218p]
A pregnant woman for four or five months, feeling depressed and sad, wept bitterly during the day, unable to stretch her limbs, appearing as if possessed by a spirit. Neither physicians nor shamans were of any help. Then, with the remedy from Mr. Guan and the jujube soup from Zhongjing, she recovered immediately.

A pregnant woman was ill, and the doctor said she might miscarriage. Qian Zhongyang remarked: "In pregnancy, the five organs provide nourishment; it generally changes every sixty days. If one adjusts appropriately during her months, why should she have a miscarriage?" In the end, both mother and child were fine.

A woman suffered from a blockage, and the more she treated it, the worse it became. Reflecting on the comment from the "Golden Coffer" about stopping treatments for cases of vomiting and purging, she halted her medications, and after a month, found peace.

A pregnant woman seven months along, felt pressure and shortness of breath in her chest, suddenly vomited something about the size of a small intestine. Her family was alarmed, thinking her fetus was rotting. When Cheng Wenbin arrived and diagnosed her pulse as strong and smooth, he realized her Qi was abundant but her blood was insufficient. The fetal Qi accumulated in the middle jiao, leading to damp heat and phlegm production. He identified the vomited substance as consolidated phlegm. The illness was named "fetal hanging," and with a formula of perilla drink augmented with Scutellaria, Coptis, and Fritillaria for ten doses, she was cured.

Madam Wang, the wife of an official, three months pregnant, experienced recurring pain in her waist and abdomen, with constant leakage and feelings of bloating and discomfort. Yan Jiang was called for a consultation. His diagnosis found her six pulses taut and numerous, in contrast to her usual deep and thin pulse, indicating anger had provoked liver fire, leading to internal heat. Despite a non-slippery pulse, she was not far from treatment failure and could still be preserved. He prescribed a decoction of Scutellaria, Atractylodes, Bitter Orange, Cyperus, Poria, donkey-hide gelatin, White Peony, Angelica, and dried tangerine peel, simmered with fine powdered calcined deer antler wine. Adding Yiping pills, she experienced relief from the pain after just one dose, and several doses later her condition stabilized.[219p]
A woman, having undergone a difficult pregnancy, experienced nausea and dizziness, struggling with her diet. The physician diagnosed her with a condition affecting the heart and spleen, noting that it was customary not to treat women in such a situation when their cycle was absent. Jiang Guan examined her and found that though her pulse was weak, it felt slippery and did not end abruptly, indicating pregnancy but not a dangerous sign. He prescribed a formula of Six Gentlemen with cardamom, taken several times, which brought her comfort.

Another woman, eight months into her pregnancy, suddenly suffered from lower back pain and was unable to turn, with constipation as well. The physician prescribed ginseng and other tonics, but the pain worsened. Using laxatives did not relieve the pain despite the constipation easing. Wang Shishan examined her pulse, finding it somewhat rapid, and concluded it was caused by heat and stagnation of blood. He recommended a formula of Four Substances with added herbs including incense, myrrh, yellow herbal, and hemp seeds. After taking four to five doses, her pain reduced, and the constipation improved, but she developed a fever and redness on her face, along with occasional chills. He adjusted the formula, removing the incense and myrrh, and adding Chai Hu and Huang Qin. After two doses, her chills and fever abated. However, she later felt cold in her back and had a recurrence of back pain; Wang remarked that blood flow had improved, and suggested adding a penny of ginseng to the previous formula. She took it and felt relief.[220p]
A woman, three months pregnant, experienced a trauma that caused pain in her waist and lower abdomen, along with bleeding and internal heat. Jiang Huang Nan prescribed Angelica, Atractylodes, Scutellaria, cooked Rehmannia, Chuanxiong, Fangfeng, Cardamom, Mugwort leaves, and Cyperus. After decocting these in water and taking the remedy, the bleeding stopped and the abdominal pain eased. He then removed the cardamom and used three egg yolks, mixing them with wine, cooking them until solid, and having her eat it, which resulted in complete recovery.

Another woman frequently experienced transverse presentations in childbirth, having seven or eight pregnancies, but none resulted in viable offspring. Wang Shishan diagnosed her pulse as fine, weak, and somewhat stringy, stating that she suffered from both qi and blood deficiency along with internal heat. Some argued that excess qi and blood were needed for pregnancy, and with both qi and blood depleted, how could she conceive? Observing her long form and fine, weak pulse indicated a deficiency in both qi and blood; a blue complexion with a stringy pulse pointed to fiery liver heat; while the two pulse positions felt floating and slippery suggested a lighter blood deficiency with heavier qi deficiency.

A formula was indicated: Yin Supplement Pills with removed dried tangerine peel, increased Cyperus, ginseng, and astragalus, to be taken as honey pills to ensure continuation of the pregnancy. After a year, she approached her due date and successfully gave birth to a son.[221p]
A woman, long and thin with a yellow-white complexion, was quick-tempered, over thirty years old, and often suffered from miscarriage, having experienced seven or eight. Wang Shishan examined her pulse, which was soft and weak; both pulses were floating yet feeble and could not endure pressure. He said: This is due to having had too many miscarriages, leading to severe depletion of qi and blood, leaving no nourishment for the fetus, hence the frequent losses. It is like water running dry causing the grain to wither, and soil being eroded causing the trees to fall. Furthermore, during the third and fifth months, it is precisely when the lesser yang fire is active, and coupled with her temperament being quick and urgent, this is why she often miscarried in the third, fifth, and seventh months. It is advisable to take a restorative decoction without cinnamon, adding huangbo and huangqin to be decocted and taken. Additionally, grinding into powder and making honey pills to take, may help preserve the pregnancy. After taking it for six months, the fetus stabilized and she gave birth to two sons.

Another woman had a fragile and small physique, her complexion nearly purple. Over a year after giving birth, her menstrual flow had stopped, and suddenly in early summer, she fell ill with vomiting, numbness in her fingers, and her fists could not open. Her voice was hoarse and soft, and she could not produce sounds. Physicians viewed her symptoms as a serious wind disease. Wang Shishan examined her and found her pulse to be fine and slippery, stating: This is due to pregancy complication. Many argued about her menstrual flow being obstructed, questioning how there could be pregnancy. Wang remarked: In this world, some matters are constant while others change; this is a case of change. Though the pulse was fine and slippery, the pulses at the wrist were not interrupted, indicating pregnancy. Thus, he treated her with Four Gentlemen Decoction plus two Chen herbs, and all her symptoms diminished. She remained wary of porridge and soup, only able to eat dry cakes and aromatic, roasted foods with some vitality.[222p]
A woman, nearing thirty years of age, was thin and pale. Occasionally, she would cough once or twice, with her menstrual cycle either early or delayed. In the summer, she sought relief from the heat and ended up coughing severely, unable to lie down for over a month. The phlegm she coughed up sometimes had blood or pus in it; when the coughing intensified, she would vomit food. Doctors prescribed herbs like Qín and Lián, as well as Er Chén, but there was no effect. They then used tonics like Ginseng and Astragalus, yet her condition worsened.

Doctor Wang Shishan examined her and found her left pulse to be floating and slippery, while her right pulse was somewhat weak and also slippery. Her wrist had been injured and could not extend, and the right pulse seemed difficult to assess. He decided to examine the left pulse again, fearing she might be pregnant with lung abscess. He then prescribed a formula to clear and drain the lungs. After three doses, she was able to lie down, did not vomit phlegm, and did not cough up pus. However, she occasionally experienced difficulty. Doctor Wang stated that this was a common ailment during pregnancy.

He recommended taking a decoction of Coix seed, Atractylodes, Poria, Ophiopogon, Huang Qin, and Ejiao, which led to an improvement. Over a month later, upon re-examination, the pulses were slightly slower and floating, and he remarked that the heat had diminished. However, she was still vomiting too much blood, which could harm her stomach. He advised a decoction of Four Gentlemen's formula with addition of Chen Pi, Huang Qin, and Zhi Ke to regulate her condition.

As her pregnancy reached six months, she had an adverse reaction after eating chicken. She stopped eating chicken and recovered. By September, her illness recurred, leading to a hoarse voice, and she was advised to take children's urine for comfort. Doctor Wang said that after childbirth, her illness would resolve, which was a good sign. He warned that if the illness recurred, it was beyond his knowledge. When the pregnancy was full term, her stomach and spleen ailments flared up, leading to excessive discharge, and ultimately, she could not be saved.[223p]
Zhong Cang Xu Shaowei sent a command to Jintan at that time, as the lady was experiencing a miscarriage, and treatment was ongoing without success. Under pressure from the upper authorities, he wished to follow the prevailing momentum and take action, consulting me. I simply instructed that she take Foshou San, believing that if it could stabilize the situation, it would; if not, it would lead to a miscarriage, allowing things to proceed naturally. After taking it several times, he remained anxious and indecisive. A female specialist in gynecology presented a prescription, which included two taels of niuxi (achyranthes) boiled in wine for consumption. She asserted that niuxi is a tonic for the lower body, so what harm could it do? He believed her and consumed it, and indeed, the fetus was expelled. At that time, there was a relative of mine from my mother’s side who was unaware, but when they rushed to inform me, I heard that the entire courtyard was filled with the fragrance of osmanthus and musk, probably because after niuxi was expelled, Xu had introduced fragrant osmanthus powder. Blood then gushed forth uncontrollably, like a river breaking its banks, and I urgently prepared a decoction of dangshen (codonopsis), but before it was ready, she passed away. The gentleman was initially filled with sorrow; as he passed by my place, he pondered aloud to me: "How could niuxi, a supplement, cause a miscarriage?" I replied: "When something is alive, it descends; when it is cooked, it supplements. Therefore, the effects of breaking blood and filling essence are like the tips of arrows supporting each other; isn’t it just niuxi? Lu jiao (deer antler) can also cause miscarriages and break blood, yet when boiled into bai jiao (white glue), it can stabilize pregnancy and stop bleeding. The ignorance of its raw nature leads to such crude practices." He lamented endlessly. I thus specially wrote this down as a warning for the world.[224p]
A woman, six or seven months pregnant, suffered from malaria, experiencing chills first and then fever, with her six pulses being floating and tense. The doctors used Chaihu and Guizhi, but to no avail. I said, "This is not an ordinary case." The other doctors found it perplexing. After several days, her condition worsened, and she sought my treatment, which involved administering Qibao San, and she recovered after one dose.

The Yellow Emperor asked how to handle a woman with heavy body toxins. Qibo replied, "If there is a problem, there is no death." The Emperor asked, "What does that mean?" Qibo explained, "When there is great accumulation, it can be disrupted. If one diminishes more than half of it, they should stop. Truly understanding the nature of medicinals and being clear on treatment methods, there should be no doubt in attacking the condition!"[225p]
The "Medical Transmission" states: A pregnant woman had both malaria and dysentery at the same time. After over two months of treatment, the malaria stopped but the dysentery worsened, with added abdominal pain and a reduced appetite. I was called to examine her. I said: It is a deficiency of cold. I prescribed a restorative formula with ginger and cassia, and after one dose, the dysentery had significantly improved. However, after another dose, the malaria worsened again. The family was alarmed, and I said: This is a good sign. The previous cessation of malaria signified an extreme dominance of yin, causing yang to hesitate in contention. Now, with the administration of the restorative yang medicine, the yang energy is empowered to contend with the yin. If we can further support the strength of yang, the yin will retreat of its own accord. I added five fen of fuzi to the formula, and both the malaria and dysentery were cured. After taking the restorative medicine thoroughly for three months, she gave birth to a son, who was very healthy after delivery.

The "Comprehensive Records of Offspring" mentions: The wife of Xiong Jing, the county magistrate of Luotian, was pregnant and suffered from pain and heat in her fifth month. She consulted a female doctor, Zhu Tinghe, who treated her for malaria. Later, she sought the help of a scholar, Wan Yuan, whose treatment added dysentery. By the eighth month, both malaria and dysentery occurred together, prompting her to ask a master for combined treatment. Upon diagnosing her pulse, I found the left hand to be deep and strong, while the right pulse was floating, large, and weak. This indicated an internal injury from male pregnancy. I used a restorative formula combined with qinghao and baizhu, and after over ten doses, both malaria and dysentery ceased. Later, she was stabilized with Hu Lian pills. In the following spring, she indeed gave birth to a boy.[226p]
